Dictionary.Name: Tlingit–English Database
Dictionary.Description: Lexical database of the Tlingit language
Dictionary.Copyright: 2011–2012 James A. Crippen; based on research by Jeff Leer, Keri Edwards Eggleston, Dick Dauenhauer, Lance Twitchell, et al.

Lemma.Comment: Suppletive positional form of %i√nuk%i, so verb themes with this root %i√.a%i can only occur as positional imperfectives.

Definition.Definition: O (sg., generic) sit, be in position at N

Grammar.Text: Unlike many other positional themes, the locative adjunct %iN-t%i is optional.

Example.Translation: Mary is just sitting at home.
Their grandmother is sitting between them.

Example.Example: Chʼa tlákw áa áwé yanéekw du kʼí.
Example.Translation: His rump hurts from just sitting all the time.

Definition.Definition: O (sg., animate) sit, be in position at N
S cause, make O (animate) sit, be positioned at N

Example.Translation: He’s put the cat in the box.
Example.Comment: Implies cat did not fight nor climb out immediately.

Example.Translation: He has his child seated on the cradleboard.

Definition.Definition: O (sg., building or construction) sit, be in position at N

Example.Example: Hít tlein át la.aayéen, kei uwagán ḵu.aa.
Example.Translation: A large house used to be there, but it burned down.

Example.Example: Ax̱ hídi ANB Hall tuwánt la.áa.
Example.Translation: My house sits next to the ANB Hall.

Example.Example: Héen tʼiká át la.áa du hídi.
Example.Translation: His house sits there beside the river.

Example.Example: Yá Aangóont áyá la.áa haa hídi Aanx̱ʼaagi Hít yóo duwasáakw.
Example.Translation: Our clan house standing in Angoon is called %iAanx̱ʼaagi Hít%i.

Definition.Definition: O (human) sit, be in position at N acting fancy
O (animate) sit idle or minding own business at home

Grammar.Text: Hapax legomenon from Leer’s notes on Tongass Tlingit. Includes inalienable incorporated noun %ita-%i ‘bottom, base’.

Definition.Comment: scruffy trees that grow in Inland Tlingit country

Example.Example: Taakw eetéede yaa ḵunahéin: kayaaní kei kana.éin.
Example.Translation: Spring is coming: plants are growing up.

Example.Example: Daa sá i táayi g̱eixʼ ka.éix̱?
Example.Translation: What is growing in (the folds of) your garden?
Mountain ash doesn’t grow in Yakutat.
Example.Comment: Note that %iYaakwdáat%i is right-dislocated leaving %iá-xʼ%i = %iáa%i behind.

Example.Translation: Speech pours out of his mouth.

Definition.Definition: O (fluid) flow out to, pour out to a point N

Example.Translation: Water flowed off the face of the cliff and down below.
Example.Comment: Note %iN-t%i and verb stem %i–.áa%i not %i–.aa%i.

Definition.Definition: S cause O to grow, S make O grow, S grow O

Example.Example: Séew ḵa g̱agaan kagánich áwé kei kanas.éin.
Example.Translation: Rain and sunlight are making it grow.
Example.Comment: Note ergative %i-ch%i applied to coordinated phrase %iséew ḵa g̱agaan kagáni%i.
Meaning that the plants grow wild.

Definition.Definition: S turn on O (hose, faucet), S cause O to flow
S turn O (hose, faucet) on N, S cause O to flow to N

Example.Translation: He turned it (hose) on the floor (causing water to pour out onto the floor).
Example.Comment: Note %iN-t%i and verb stem %i–.áa%i not %i–.aa%i.

Definition.Definition: S spray water out from O (hose, nozzle)

Example.Translation: They sprayed it (water) on each other (from hoses).

Definition.Comment: Originally applied only to long objects, e.g. hair or plants with long stems, now generalized to any object as with the parent verb theme.

Example.Comment: Is this example an imperative causative instead?

Definition.Definition: O poke up, stick up from N

Example.Translation: It (porcupine quills) are sticking out of him.
It is sticking out from over there.

Definition.Definition: O (plural sticklike) poke up, stick up from N

Example.Translation: His hair (fur, quills) is sticking up.
It (mountain peak) sticks up over there.
Porcupine quills are sticking up all over his body.

Definition.Definition: O’s butt poke up, stick up

Example.Translation: They’re over there with their buttocks in the air.
They had their behinds sticking up.
His facial hairs have started to sprout.
Example.Notes: May actually be %ikéi x̱alukawdzi.áa%i with %ix̱a-%i ‘hair, fur’ rather than %ix̱ʼa-%i ‘mouth’.

Example.Example: Du téix̱ʼ daanáx̱ kʼé shukawdzi.áa wé kawóot.
Example.Translation: That tumor, it’s really grown around his heart.

Definition.Comment: %iḵei-%i with uvular lowering is used in more northerly communities, e.g. Hoonah, Chilkat, Yakutat

Example.Translation: If it’s gotten to summer, it’s daylight at nine.
Example.Comment: This illustrates the meaning ‘daylight’ versus ‘dawn’, since dawn is actually much earlier in the summer.

Definition.Comment: note both S and O are added unlike other causatives that only add one argument

Example.Translation: They are going to celebrate Christmas.

VerbTheme.DerivGloss: back and forth + land + horiz. surface

Grammar.Text: Sole example of the alienable incorporated noun %iaan-%i ‘land’. The %iyoo=%i ‘back and forth’ preverb is obligatory in all forms. Normally impersonal hence taking no object or subject, but N&S give the example %iyú aan yoo kaya.éik%i ‘the land quakes’ where the %iaan%i is an ordinary noun and thus the object argument of the verb.

Definition.Definition: S swim with head emerging occasionally
Definition.Comment: esp. seal, other fur-bearing marine mammals

Example.Translation: A seal is swimming along and putting its head out of the water every little while.
That seal keeps poking out his head.

Definition.Definition: S move S’s face around N

Example.Example: Tlax̱ de %iJesus%i yáx̱ áwé át yawdzi.aa.
Example.Translation: He was just going around there showing his face like he was Jesus.
Example.Comment: Meaning that he was acting aloof and superior.

Definition.Definition: S swim around N with head emerging occasionally

Example.Translation: It looks around and then goes down again.

Definition.Definition: S move S’s face towards N

Example.Translation: He stuck his head under the table.

Lemma.Comment: Only occurs with incorporated inalienable noun %iÿa-%i ‘vertical surface, face’ that does not seem to contribute any synchronic meaning.

Definition.Definition: S delay, stall, detain, hinder, distract, divert, hold up, slow down O
S delay, stall, detain, hinder, distract, divert, hold up, slow down O

Grammar.Text: Some speakers have this variant with a thematic irrealis prefix. The meaning seems to be exactly the same, so that the irrealis apparently has no semantic function. The classifier I-component agrees with the irrealis so that it always exhibits the [−I] feature.

Definition.Definition: O be delayed, stalled, detained, hindered, distracted, diverted, held up, slowed down
O be slow, take time, make slow progress
O (animate) be troubled, bothered, hindered mentally by S
O (human) be delayed in speaking, be interrupted by S
O be delayed, held back in speech, be slow to speak
O be delayed in speaking by S (= N)

Grammar.Text: It is unclear how this theme is different from the theme above that is also transitive.

Example.Comment: This example shows a terminative derivation with %iÿan=%i and ∅-conjugation class.

Lemma.Comment: Inland Tlingit

Grammar.Text: Only rarely used without a postposition. Bare %iá%i is more likely to be the focus particle.

Encyclopedia.Text: The dividing lines between human, nonhuman animate, and inanimate are somewhat vague. Third person human pronouns are occasionally used for animate things like mammals, fish, and birds, and the third person nonhuman is sometimes heard with an obviously human referent. These differences in usage, if they are at all consistent, are subtle and have yet to be explored.

Grammar.Text: This sense only seems to arise when used with a locational postposition, namely %i-xʼ%i ~ %i-ʼ%i, %i-dáx̱%i, %i-dé%i, %i-g̱áa%i, %i-náx̱%i, %ináḵ%i %i-t%i, %i-ú%i, or %i-x̱%i. When used alone the pronoun %iá%i never seems to refer to a location.

Usually suffixed with a demonstrative like %iwé%i or %iyá%i, or with a question particle like %igé%i. Extremely difficult to translate into English and therefore often ignored, but its presence or absence has a demonstrable impact on the interpretation of a sentence. Needs more careful semantic analysis; probably not a true ‘focus’ operator in the sense of formal syntax and semantics.

Example.Translation: I’m going to haul a lot of food to the potlatch.

Grammar.Text: Formally identical with the focus particle but found in sentences without verbs where the lack of the particle would be ungrammatical. Strange and probably ungrammatical when used without a demonstrative suffix.
Indicates emphasis when used sentence-finally, usually occuring alone without any suffixes. The usage of this sense can be thought of as ‘focusing’ the entire sentence, hence producing the emphasis.

Example.Translation: I will see you again, for sure!

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘some of night’.

Example.Example: Daaḵw aa sá yi tuwáa sigóo?
Example.Translation: Which one do you guys want?
He made a spearhead, a new one.

Example.Example: Tlél ushkʼéiyi aa yoo x̱ʼatánk áwé tsá a.ax̱ji nooch.
Example.Translation: She always only hears the talk that is bad.
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘the talk, some that is bad’.

Grammar.Text: Same phonological form and largely the same meaning as the pronoun, but used as the possessum of another noun. This context is ungrammatical for other pronouns, e.g. %i*hasdu x̱oo wa.é%i ‘you among them’, so that this sense of %iaa%i is actually an inalienable noun rather than a pronoun.

Example.Example: A x̱oo aa gé i tuwáa sigóo?
Example.Translation: Do you want some of them?
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘ones among them’, ‘some among it’.

Definition.Definition: Sentence-initial particle, described as meaningless but functions to introduce a speech unit (narrative chunk, conversation turn, etc.)

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*ʔaːw̃%i < %i*ʔaːŋ%i; cf. Eyak %iʔąː%i ‘river’, perh. connected to Eyak %imaː%i ‘lake’ & PA %i*wən%i ‘lake’

Grammar.Text: This is one of the few words ending with the long vowel %iaa%i that act as though they are rounded despite not being pronounced that way. The result is that a suffix will appear with its rounded allomorph if one exists. Thus %iáaxʼw%i ‘at a lake’, %iáakʼw%i ‘little lake’; the unrounded forms %i*áaxʼ%i and %i*áakʼ%i are incorrect. This covert rounding is indicated phonologically by the superscript parenthesized %i⁽ʷ⁾%i, but in ordinary writing the form is always %iáa%i.

Example.Translation: I see waves on the lake.

Example.Example: Yagéi a kaayí wé áa tlein.
Example.Translation: It’s big across that big lake.

Grammar.Text: Formed from %iá%i ‘it; there’ and the %i-ʼ%i allomorph of the locative suffix %i-xʼ%i.

Example.Example: Du taayí gukshitú áwé, tleiḵw áa akaawahaa.
Example.Translation: She planted berries there, in the corner of her garden.

Example.Example: Áa gax̱toolʼoon yé yinaadé yaa gagú.
Example.Translation: Walk toward that place where we will hunt.

Grammar.Text: The meaning indicates that the verb is probably stative, but no imperfective form has been documented. The noun %iáa%i ‘lake’ exhibits covert rounding so this verb root can be expected to behave similarly.

Example.Translation: He bought a spear, a new one.

Definition.Definition: For it, around it, after it

Example.Example: Dax̱adooshú yagiyee shunaaxéex aag̱áa daak wusitani yé.
Example.Translation: The way it (rain) has been coming down, for seven days passing.
We will search for them, those medicines.

Definition.Comment: as used to introduce a new scene in narratives

Grammar.Text: The third person nonhuman %iá%i is a discourse pronoun in this construction, referring to the situation that was expressed in the preceding segment of the discourse.

Example.Example: Náakw sʼé áa yéi kḵwa.óo ax̱ keey, aag̱áa tsá wé kashóokʼ gwéil.
Example.Translation: First I’ll put medicine there on my knee, afterwards the heating pad.

Example.Example: Aag̱áa áwé, yi tula.eesháani káx̱ áwé gági uwagudi yé yáx̱ ax̱ tusitee, yá yi éesh du sʼáaxu.
Example.Translation: It’s then, I feel like it’s come out for your grief, this your father’s hat.

Definition.Definition: Auke Lake (Eng. pron. /ɒk/), the small freshwater lake behind Auke Bay north of Juneau

Example.Translation: The woman camped at Auke Bay.

Definition.Definition: The ḵwáan named after the lake, possessing the area from Juneau north to about the middle of Lynn Canal

Example.Translation: The Auke Bay People are dancing.

Grammar.Text: The noun %iáa%i ‘lake’ with the diminutive suffix %i-kʼ%i.

Example.Example: Wé áakʼw déint áwé, át woogoot, wé sheech dzískʼu tlein.
Example.Translation: Around the pond, it was walking around there, that big cow moose.

Grammar.Text: In Southern & Tongass Tlingit this is the normal term for ‘grandparent’ and %i–léelkʼw%i is not used. Leer also lists %i–éili%i as occurring in Yakutat but does not discuss its meaning or use.
Apparently in Transitional Tlingit this term is used specifically for ‘grandfather’ where differentiated from female grandparents, with %i–léelkʼw%i covering both males and females.

Lemma.Comment: Also %iAalséix̱ Héen(i)%i; sometimes reduced to %iAlséix̱%i.

Encyclopedia.Text: The individual who rests, and the exact place that they do so, are both unclear. Raven is a speculative but likely candidate.

Example.Example: Ḵʼalkátsk yáxwchʼich yax̱ yawsix̱áa haa aaní kaadáx̱.
Example.Translation: Sea otters have devoured the yellowneck clams from our land.

Definition.Comment: no distinction is made for population size

Grammar.Text: Combination of third person nonhuman pronoun %iá%i ‘it’ and instrumental %i-n%i.

Example.Example: Aan adulʼeix̱ ax̱áa kaḵachʼáakʼwt áyá áa x̱at jikawduwaḵaa.
Example.Translation: I have been commissioned to carve a paddle with which to dance.

Example.Example: Aan áwé shóot ax̱wdi.ák, wé kayeix̱tág̱u.
Example.Translation: With them I built a fire, the wood shavings.

Lemma.Notes: Need more examples of modes to ensure that this is invariable. Tongass invariability is verified.

Definition.Definition: S weaken O from inactivity, cause O to be(come) weak through inactivity, make O bedridden
O be(come) bedridden, be(come) weak from inactivity

Grammar.Text: This is not a reflexive, there is an object rather than a subject and there is no %ish-%i.

Example.Translation: Get up; you could become bedridden.
Example.Comment: Potential mode.

Lemma.Notes: Need to verify that these themes are stv impfv only, or if they can be pfv etc.

Grammar.Text: Naish & Story did not list this theme in their dictionary but it appears in their notes.

Example.Translation: His soul is at peace (reflected in his behaviour).

Example.Example: Ax̱ tʼaaḵxʼí, gunalchéesh aadé x̱aan yituli.aani yé.
Example.Translation: My brothers, thank you for the way you have been kind to me.
They haven’t been kind to me.

Example.Example: Haa ḵoon sh kalnéegi áwé ḵúnáx̱ tuli.aan.

Grammar.Text: Hapax legomenon, only known from L-vb source. The function of %ika-%i here is unclear.

Definition.Definition: O be kind in words, talk kindly, gently

Grammar.Text: Naish & Story did not list this theme in their dictionary but it appears in their notes.
Only known from Leer; he gives a theme without examples, but includes a nominalized phrase from Inland Tlingit from which we can reconstruct this verb theme.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘just from unkindness, ingentility’.

Grammar.Text: Hapax legomenon, only known from one example. Includes thematic irrealis %iu-%i.
Includes thematic irrealis %iu-%i.

Example.Translation: It has a pleasant face the way that you (sg.) have made it (totem pole).

Example.Example: Jilkaatdáx̱ áwé has wulig̱áasʼ; tle Aangóonxʼ has wudzi.aan.
Example.Translation: They moved away from Chilkat; they settled in Angoon.

Definition.Definition: An unidentified kind of fish trap

Encyclopedia.Text: Said to be larger than the kind called %inoow%i, but this is the only information recorded about it in Leer’s notes.

Lemma.Comment: N&S gloss this as ‘fern’ in their notes, probably misunderstood in a fern-digging narrative.

Definition.Definition: Digging stick, digging tool, tool used for planting

Encyclopedia.Text: So named because the original village site was built on a low isthmus between the main island and a hill.

Lemma.Comment: Also %iAankich%i, %iÁankích%i, etc. Southern %iÁànkích%i is expected but undocumented.

Definition.Definition: Anchorage, the largest city in Alaska

Encyclopedia.Text: Anchorage is the largest city in Alaska, located in the southcentral part of the state at the head of Cook Inlet. It is just outside of the Pacific Northwest rainforest which ends at Girdwood about 50 km (35 mi) to the southeast. Instead, the climate in Anchorage is more similar to that in Inland Tlingit country, although moderated somewhat by the oceanic waters of Cook Inlet. Anchorage is in the traditional territory of the Denaʼina (Tl. %iDanaaynaa%i, q.v.) who did not have much contact with the Tlingit until the 20th century. Though not as many as in the Seattle region, a considerable number of Tlingits live in Anchorage today. Tlingit speakers in Anchorage are few, however. Given the extensive mudflats surrounding the city, a jocular Tlingit name for Anchorage is %iLein.aan%i ‘Mudflat Town’; another less specific name is %iAan Tlein%i ‘Big City’.

Example.Translation: It is called %iÁankich%i in Tlingit, Anchorage.
There are many Tlingits living in Anchorage.

Encyclopedia.Text: Applies esp. to conifers, but can refer to broadleaf trees well. Although western hemlock is the dominant tree on the coast, the prototypical tree seems to be Sitka spruce. The distinction between tree and bush is fuzzy, but generally trees are taller than humans and bushes are not; this essentially parallels English usage.

Some people have this as their specific term for Sitka spruce as well as for trees in general, and lack the term %ishéiyi%i. This is probably at least partly due to the status of the Sitka spruce as a sort of prototypical tree among the Coastal Tlingit.

Example.Example: Yakʼéiyi x̱ʼayeit áwé du jeewú ax̱ aat.
Example.Translation: My paternal aunt has nice dishes.

Example.Example: We hoon sʼaatí een yóo x̱ʼali.átk ax̱ aat.
Example.Translation: My paternal aunt is talking with the storekeeper.

Lemma.Comment: Often reduced to %iÁatlin%i or %iÁatlen%i

Definition.Definition: Atlin Lake (Eng. pron. /ˈætˌlɪn/) and its surrounding area

Encyclopedia.Text: May have been calqued from a local Ath. name now lost. The obsolete English name %iAtlinto Lake%i includes an Ath. (Tag.?) %i-tuʼ%i ‘lake’ suffix, forming a multilingual pleonasm ‘big lake lake lake’.

Definition.Definition: The Atlin Ḵwáan, who possess Atlin Lake and the upper Taku River and its headwaters

Encyclopedia.Text: Sometimes referred to as ‘Taku River people’ in English, esp. in British Columbia (cf. ‘Taku River First Nation’), though this is unfaithful to the Tlingit tradition where the %iTʼaaḵú Ḵwáan%i claim the lower Taku River and the coast up to Juneau; the traditional division between the Atlin and Taku Ḵwáan has been usurped by artificial international divisions. The area was at least partially inhabited by an Athabaskan-speaking group called ‘Taku Athabaskans’ as documented by early European explorers. These predecessors seem to have been wholly absorbed by the Tlingit group. The Atlin Ḵwáan waged a long and bitter war against the Tahltan in the upper Stikine and Taku watersheds. The Tlingit dialect of Atlin is more like Coastal Tlingit than other Inland dialects, with fewer Athabaskan loanwords and a near total lack of %im%i. Like much of Inland Tlingit, Atlin speech has some affinities with Transitional Tlingit not found in e.g. Juneau or Haines.

Definition.Definition: The Ahtna people of the Copper River valley

Grammar.Text: Novel borrowing, used by people unaware of the traditional name %iIḵkaa Ḵwáan%i. Sometimes actually a codeswitched English name, but note the final vowel length and quality.
Looks suspiciously like a verb %ia-dla-g̱áa%i from %ia-∅-[+D,l,−I]-√g̱áa˟%i, but not conjugable or otherwise morphosyntactically verbal.

Example.Translation: She is weaving yellow-cedar bark for a mat.

Definition.Definition: S weave on the face of O
S make, build a fire at N

Example.Translation: I built a fire in it.
Did they already build a fire there?
They’ll build a fire under it.

Example.Comment: Imperative, but a specialized meaning.

Example.Translation: We will build a fire in the morning.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘thing he washes the surface of it on’

Example.Translation: I tried to look at your face.
Example.Comment: Describes trying to get a person’s attention.

Example.Example: Chʼa akaawa.aaḵw áwé, wáa sá yakwg̱aḵaayí.
Example.Translation: He tested him to see what he would say.
Example.Comment: Subordinate clause is adjunct, not object.

Lemma.Notes: Listed as invariable because it only occurs as a positional, could also be variable with only the %i-n%i stem attested.

Definition.Definition: S sit quietly at N, meditate at N

Example.Translation: He’s sitting quietly on the steps of his porch meditating.

Definition.Definition: S sit watching the weather at N

Example.Translation: People used to sit outside watching the weather.

Definition.Definition: Aleut, indigenous inhabitants of the Aleutian Chain and the western end of the Alaska Peninsula
Alutiiq, indigenous inhabitants of the southeastern Alaska Peninsula, the Kodiak Islands, and the southern Kenai Peninsula

Encyclopedia.Text: Some speakers lump the Alutiiq and Aleut together, others distinguish them. Tlingits from more southerly Southeast Alaska or from Inland Tlingit country may not distinguish Alutiiq from Sugpiaq (%iGiyáḵw%i, %iGutéix̱ʼ%i).

Applied to all Russians, past and present, both within and outside of Alaska. The Russians played the major role in European–Tlingit interactions for nearly a century, but they have mostly faded into history in the modern Tlingit world. Attitudes towards the historic Russians vary widely among the Tlingit, with some reviling them and some seeing them in a fairly positive light. Attitudes towards modern Russians are somewhat coloured by history but not especially prejudiced.

Grammar.Text: Grammaticalized form of %iat daayí%i ‘its skin’ with indefinite nonhuman possessor %iat%i.

Encyclopedia.Text: Known more specifically in English as ‘paper birch’ or ‘canoe birch’. Named in Tlingit after its peeling bark.

Grammar.Text: Perh. %itlákw%i preceded by focus particle, or simply a prothetic vowel.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘thing through which people suck something’
lit. ‘thing through which people strain something’
in a legal sense, by extension of the basic meaning
separated from animal, not incl. skin

Grammar.Text: Grammaticalized form of %iat x̱aawú%i ‘something’s fur’ with indefinite nonhuman possessor %iat%i.

Definition.Definition: Skin scraper for graining and dehairing.

Grammar.Text: Deverbal noun from %iat yawsiḵaa%i ‘he promised’.

Example.Example: Chʼa tlákw a kát satée nooch, du atyawusḵaayí.
Example.Translation: He always remembers them, his promises.

Definition.Definition: There, at that place. Formed from %iá%i ‘it; there’ and the %i-xʼ%i locative suffix

Lemma.Comment: Denotes understanding of speech with incorporated noun %ix̱ʼa-%i ‘mouth’ and listening to speech with inalienable adjunct %i–x̱ʼé%i ‘mouth’. Use of repetitive %i-ch%i can be epiaspectual and thus produce a new paradigm where the root appears to be invariable %i√.áx̱ch˟%i.

Example.Example: Tléil ushkʼéiyi aa yoo x̱'atánk áwé tsá a.ax̱ji nooch.
Example.Translation: She always only hears the talk that is bad.
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘the talk, some that is bad’.

Grammar.Text: Pseudopassive form with indefinite human subject %idu-%i, thus literally ‘someone hears O’, ‘people hear O’. Presence of %idu-%i replaces [+D] with [-D] in the ∅-series classifier, so this may have a hidden [+D] and thus middle voice.

The semantics here are opaque. The allative %i-dé%i would imply a meaning like ‘toward N’s mouth’, but the interpretation instead seems to be ‘from N’s mouth’. This seems to be idiomatic and unpredictable.

Example.Comment: Used ironically for a person who is hard of hearing.
Orig. %iʟēł acq!ē′kuᴀx%i.

Example.Example: Chʼu l ash x̱ʼéi ḵoo.áax̱ áwé a daak uwagút kawlitʼéexʼ gwáaÿá.
Example.Translation: Before he could hear him (listen to him), it seems he went up and found him stiff (dead).
Example.Comment: Orig. %itcuł acq!ē′kuāxawe′ ā′dāk ū′wagut kaołit!ê′k gwâỵᴀ′%i.

Example.Translation: Maybe I heard a bear’s voice.
I barely hear it on the island.

Definition.Definition: S finally hear O after mishearing

Example.Translation: Do you finally hear it? (Do you understand it now?)

Lemma.Etymology: From an uncertain Ath. lg., prob. %i*ʔə-yuˑn%i or %ikʼə-yuˑn%i ‘different’ per Leer.

Definition.Definition: Dene or Athabaskan, specifically one of the groups in the upper Yukon River region: Southern Tutchone, Northern Tutchone, Hän, Gwichʼin

Lemma.Comment: Derived from %i√.ax̱%i and the repetitive %i-ch%i but is actually a variable root. Probably based on the repetitive epiaspect with %i-ch%i. Stem variation is still unclear, as is why the root is glottalized in Tongass.
Lemma.Notes: Investigate stem variation, testing both %iga-%i and %ig̱a%i-conjugation. Can this take %i-ch%i again? Maybe only the Tongass one is variable?

VerbTheme.Notes: Need examples with stems other than %i–.áx̱ch%i.

Grammar.Text: With %iga%i-conjugation, this theme means to understand a language, or speech in that language. Ability to speak is implied.

Example.Comment: Meaning that he doesn’t understand the language.

VerbTheme.Notes: Need non-Tongass examples.

Definition.Definition: S learn to understand O’s speech, language

Grammar.Text: With %ig̱a%i-conjugation this theme means to learn to understand a language. Ability to speak is implied.

Lemma.Comment: Inland dial. only, elsewhere %igwátaa%i.

Grammar.Text: Unusually contains a labial stop which is not normally a Tlingit phoneme.
In Northern Tlingit the imperative %ikalachá%i is often reduced to %iklachá%i.

Example.Translation: He strained the boiled berries through cheesecloth.
He has already been straining the water.
Example.Comment: Decessive active imperfective.

Example.Translation: He always strains his tea before he drinks it.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘thing through which people strain something’

Lemma.Notes: Check if this can be possessed, and hence if alienable.

Definition.Definition: Opposite, a term of respect for a member of the moiety opposite the speaker

Definition.Notes: Need examples to clarify this sense.

Encyclopedia.Text: Although the English term ‘Chinaman’ is now considered insulting, the Chinook Jargon and Tlingit terms derived from it are not derogatory.

Definition.Definition: East Asian, by extension from Chinese

Encyclopedia.Text: Can apply to Japanese, Korean, Filipino, etc. Some speakers feel that this is inappropriate for certain Asian groups, e.g. Thai, Vietnamese, Mongolian, although alternative Tlingit terms are lacking. Never extended to South Asians (Indian, Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Nepali, etc.).

Subentry.Etymology: perh. calqued from an unattested CJ term, or perh. a local invention
Subentry.Comment: A few speakers have %isáasu%i with unpredictable rounding.

Grammar.Text: Generally restricted to areas where Russian influence was extensive, though still spreading.

Lemma.Etymology: < Ru. чаю %ičáyu%i ‘some tea’, dative/partitive form of чай %ičay%i ‘tea’ < Chinese lgs., cf. Mandarin %ichà%i

Grammar.Text: Primarily used on the coast, mostly from Wrangell northward. The possessed form can be either marked as e.g. %iax̱ cháayuwú%i ‘my tea’ or unmarked as e.g. %iax̱ cháayu%i ‘my tea’.

Encyclopedia.Text: The borrowing comes not simply from Russian чай %ičay%i but from the dative case form чаю %ičayu%i. The dative form is used as a partitive ‘some of’, as in the phrase «Давайте выпьём чаю» %i“Daváyte vɨpʸyóm čáyu”%i “Let’s drink some tea”.

VerbTheme.Notes: Needs more investigation.

Definition.Definition: O be drowsy or sleepy from overindulging in food or drink

Example.Translation: The seal fat has made him drowsy.

Definition.Definition: O stink, smell strongly and unpleasantly

Example.Translation: When the slime rots it stinks.

Lemma.Notes: Only attested in pfv examples so impfv stem variation is unknown.

Example.Translation: Opposite of it (the sun) there it is shadowed.

Grammar.Text: This noun can be either an inalienable noun or an alienable noun without any modification. Thus it appears as both %ia chéx̱ʼi%i ‘shadow of it’ with a possessor and as %ichéx̱ʼi%i ‘shadow’ without a possessor. The final %i-i%i is probably the verb nominalizing suffix meaning ‘-er’, so the word is literally ‘shader’. It is not normally pluralized, unlike Eng. ‘shadows’.

Example.Example: Wé aas chéx̱ʼi tayeet áwé tooḵéen.
Example.Translation: We are sitting underneath the shade of the tree.
He is hidden in the shadows.

Definition.Definition: Bald eagle, locally usually just ‘eagle’ in English

Encyclopedia.Text: The largest bird of prey in Tlingit country, with a wingspan of up to 2.25 m (7½ ft) and weighing 3.5–6.5 kg (8–14 lb). Body and wings are dark brown, legs are bright yellow without feathers below the thigh, beak is bright yellow and sharply hooked. Adults have a white head and tail, but juveniles are mottled brown until about 5 years. In the Chilkat Valley over three thousand gather in the fall to feed on late run salmon. Nests are very large, near the water, usually with few branches above; they may be found in any large tree but cottonwood, hemlock, and spruce are common. Bald eagles mainly eat fish but will eat nearly any meat including carrion. They sometimes swim on the surface, especially when towing a large salmon.

The bald eagle is a primary crest of the Wolf/Eagle moiety, having gradually replaced the Wolf in prominence through the 20th century. It is speculated that the shift from Wolf to Eagle was due to Haida influence because that culture has a Raven vs. Eagle moiety system and contact between the two cultures was particularly from the early 20th century onwards. The Haida moieties are actually the reverse of Tlingit, with Haida Eagle ≈ Tl. Raven and Haida Raven ≈ Tl. Wolf/Eagle.
Juvenile bald eagles are mottled brown until about 5 years of age, after which they develop the dark brown body and wings with white head and tail of mature adults.

Applies to any species of the genus %iSalix%i that occurs in Tlingit territory. This includes but is not limited to Arctic, netted, creeping, variable, Barclay’s, Hooker’s, Pacific, Scouler’s, Alaska, and Sitka willows.

Grammar.Text: Appears to have a fossilized possessive suffix %i-ÿí%i but is inalienable.
Used for something having unnaturally become spotted, usually temporarily.

Definition.Definition: O be spotted, polka dotted, variegated

Grammar.Text: Used for something naturally having spots, or being permanently spotted.

Example.Example: Kadlichʼáchʼx̱i yé yáx̱ yatee du kináanáx̱.
Example.Translation: Like how the way it (a flicker) is spotted on top.

Example.Example: Tsaa doogú kadlichʼáchʼx̱: ḵúnáx̱ áwé yakʼéi.
Example.Translation: A seal skin is spotted: that’s really good.

Definition.Definition: O be spotted, polka dotted, variegated

Grammar.Text: Used for something naturally having spots, or being permanently spotted.

Lemma.Comment: Meaning unclear. Noted by Leer from Kelly & Willard %ichʼáalʼ%i ‘pale’ with comment from ‘J’ saying ‘as one gets when embarrassed’. The %i-x̱%i stv impfv of verb given by Leer from ‘J’ is the lone example.

Nonverb.Notes: Needs to be verified, may be hapax.

Definition.Definition: Pale, as one gets when embarrassed

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘what did you fish?’
Lit. ‘what bothered you?’

Grammar.Text: When used with following %isá%i and not in a question, the meaning is a generic quantifier ‘whatever’ or ‘anything’.

Example.Example: Daa sá li.oos áwé náxwx̱ dulyeix̱ín.
Example.Translation: Whatever was playful was made into (carved) halibut hooks.

Definition.Definition: Around, about, surrounding, outside of something

Example.Example: Wé x̱ʼakaskéin daaxʼ áwé yéi jiné.
Example.Translation: She is working on the outside of the unfinished basket.

Example.Example: I tuḵʼatáali i daax̱ yei jeekanaxíx.
Example.Translation: Your pants are falling down around you.
It rubs along the skin (on a baby, causing a rash).

Example.Example: Du l x̱ʼeishkʼeiyí daax̱ áyú kei x̱ʼakdutéix̱ʼch.
Example.Translation: They’re trying to twist his mouth because of (about) his improper speech.

Definition.Definition: Weasel, either the long-tailed or short-tailed species

Encyclopedia.Text: Known as a “stoat” in Europe. Tlingits appreciate its soft white winter fur which is used especially in hats.
Similar to Hebrew %hאָמֵן%h %iʔāmēn%i and hence Greek ἀμήν %iamḗn%i and Russian ами́нь %iamínʼ%i, though not used in Tlingit translations of religious materials.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %idaʰ-ka-ʔat%i ‘around-horiz.surface-thing’ with standard reduction of %i–ka-ʔat%i to %i–keʰt%i.

Grammar.Text: May be part of either a posessesed or non-possessed compound, the former as %idaakeidí%i.

Definition.Definition: Money, including paper currency, coinage, and electronic or abstract money

Example.Example: Ax̱ dáanaayí a wanáa yéi aa na.óo.
Example.Translation: Put my money separate from the rest.
He did him wrong and so paid him with money.

Definition.Definition: Dollar, either US or Canadian currency, or by extension any other country’s currency called ‘dollar’ in English

Encyclopedia.Text: Because of the different coins and bills in use, in Canada this is more likely to be used with a small round object handling verb, versus a flat flexible object handling verb in the US.

Definition.Definition: Rich person, one who is wealthy
Silversmith, one who makes jewelry or art using silver

VerbTheme.Notes: Probably ∅-conjugation, but needs to be tested via e.g. potential or habitual form.

Definition.Definition: O be wealthy, have lots of money

Example.Translation: He was wealthy from his knowledge.

Lemma.Etymology: Unknown, but appears to be from a verb.

Definition.Definition: Hummingbird, either Rufous hummingbird or Anna’s hummingbird

Encyclopedia.Text: A secondary crest of the %iLukaax̱.ádi%i clan. The two species are not differentiated traditionally. The rufous hummingbird regularly migrates to the region to breed. The male has a white breast, rusty-red (rufous) face, and an iridescent orange patch on the throat, with occasional green on the back or crown. Females have a green back and mottled white and rufous belly. Anna’s hummingbird is an occasional visitor. The male has an iridescent red throat and crown, green back and sides, and grey chest and belly. Females and juveniles have a green crown, and a grey throat with occasional red spots, and grey chest and belly. Both are very territorial and will fight with many other birds, even sometimes confronting crows or ravens.

Definition.Definition: Black spruce, jack pine, swamp spruce, muskeg spruce
Definition.Comment: scruffy coniferous trees that grow in Inland Tlingit country and elsewhere in the interior

Encyclopedia.Text: A short to medium height spruce tree, often as small as a bush but can be up to 25 m (80 ft) tall. Not actually the jack pine %iPinus banksiana%i (Lamb. 1803) though often referred to as such in Canada. As a spruce it is evergreen and coniferous, but may be found bare yet alive due to recent fire. Very slow growing, but outcompetes most other trees in muskeg environments. Usually has a scruffy habit, narrowly cone shaped to spire-like. Infections may produce a tangled “witch’s broom” appearance, and exposure to wind or ice may produce a stunted, twisted shape. Bark is thin, grey-brown, and scaly. Needles are 0.5–1.5 cm (¼–⅔ in) long, four-angled, blue-green above and pale green below, with sharp tips. Cones are small, 1.5–3 cm (⅔–1¼ in) long and 1–2 cm (½–¾ in) wide, dark purple when new and ripening to reddish brown, hanging from branches mostly in the crown. Little used in Tlingit culture, the wood is often very dense due to its slow growth and hence narrow growth rings. The most common uses are for firewood and for poles and walking sticks. Consumption of the pitch is unreported, but it is occasionally used for caulking and gluing especially in impromptu repairs.

Definition.Definition: Denaʼina, the Dene (Ath.) people of southcentral Alaska

Grammar.Text: The ending %i-naa%i is part of the borrowing, but it matches the indigenous term as in %iDeikeenaa%i ‘Haida’.

Definition.Definition: Ablative postposition: from (place), out of (place), after (time)

Example.Example: Hítxʼi tóoxʼ yaawagút yú shaawát ajaag̱idáx̱.
Example.Translation: The woman went through the houses after she killed it.

Lemma.Etymology: prob. < CJ %ilidí%i < Fr. %ile thé%i < Chinese lgs., cf. S. Min %iti%i, in Inland Tl. poss. directly from Fr.; poss. < Eng. %itea%i but Tl. initial is %id%i and not expected %it%i

Grammar.Text: Found in Southern Tlingit and in Inland Tlingit where the influence of Russian was not great. Unknown on the central and northern coast. Losing ground to %icháayu%i elsewhere on the coast, but still stable in Canada.

Encyclopedia.Text: Applies to both the Alaskan Haida traditionally living on southern Prince of Wales Island and the Canadian Haida traditionally living on Haida Gwaii. The Haida have a moiety system which is the opposite of the Tlingit, so that Tlingit Raven ≡ Haida Eagle, and Tlingit Wolf/Eagle ≡ Haida Raven. Tlingits traditionally consider the Haida to be masters of art, canoe carving, and woodwork, as well as friends and trading partners. In the past they were also respected for their skills in war and were considered formidable opponents.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %idi-kiːn%i ‘??-above’ < PND %i*kʸi(ː)ŋ%i ‘above’, related to %i*kʸe/i(ː)ŋ%i ‘head’; cf. Eyak %i–łə-tsįˀ-d%i ‘above the head of’
< %i*di-kiːn-deʰ%i ‘??-above-toward’ < PND %i*kʸi(ː)ŋ%i ‘above’, related to %i*kʸe/i(ː)ŋ%i ‘head’; Tl. preserves the PND final nasal only in this suffixed form

Grammar.Text: The primary imperfective form of this theme always contains the conjugation prefix %ig̱a-%i, unlike other stative imperfectives but similar to multipositional stative imperfectives. As with other stative verb themes, the imperfective is more common than the perfective.

Example.Translation: Snow is deep in the bottom of a ravine.

Example.Example: Kaldaag̱éináx̱ yaa g̱ax̱tooḵóox̱, tléil g̱wadlaan yá éix̱ʼ yík.
Example.Translation: We’ll motor along slowly, it’s not deep in this slough.

Grammar.Text: Leer’s notes imply this stative exists, though we lack examples of it in use. The noun class here is grain-like or marble-like particles, possibly also including coin-like objects.

VerbTheme.DerivGloss: ashore; to ground; to rest; completely

Grammar.Text: This is either the %iÿan~ÿax̱~ÿánde=%i motion derivation or the terminative non-motion derivation; extant examples are unclear so the motion derivation has been assumed here. The motion derivation, if applicable, could mean either ‘to ground’ or ‘to rest’, but ‘ashore’ is nonsensical and ‘completely’ seems unlikely. There are no attested examples of the imperfective, but it could be %iyan kaadlaan%i, in which it is impossible to tell if the conjugation prefix is present, but if this is a motion derivation then an imperfective might be impossible.

Example.Translation: The pine needles have gotten deep there.

Grammar.Text: This is a comparative derivation which is predictable, but the form can be surprising. Note that this %ika-%i does not provide the ‘small round object’.

Definition.Definition: S make O deep at N

Grammar.Text: The stative imperfective form is assumed, examples of the primary imperfective are lacking. Conjugation class must be %ig̱a%i because of the repetitive imperfective with %iyei=%i and %i-ch%i.

Example.Translation: People make the moss thick there.

Definition.Definition: S make O deep at N
S pile, layer O deeply at N

Grammar.Text: Conjugation class Stative imperfective is assumed given that this is just derivation with %ika-%i. Noun class is, as above, grain-like or marble-like particles.

Example.Example: Dleit aadé x̱waaxwéin: a káa kax̱wlidlaan.
Example.Translation: I shoveled snow that way: I made it deep there.

Example.Comment: Orig. %ikax̱adlaan%i, but appears to be imperative which should be %ikag̱adlaan%i instead.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %idliʰÿ%i; cf. Eyak %i–tseˀ%i ‘flesh, meat’, PA %i*–tsʼənʼʸ%i ‘id.’; alternatively < PT %i*d-łi⁽⁾ŋ%i ‘(meat) be fresh’ < PND %i*di-łe⁽⁾ŋ%i ‘id.’ > PA %i*d-leːnʸ%i e.g. %idəleːnʸ%i ‘(meat) is fresh; (wood) is green’

Example.Example: Wé g̱uwakaan dleeyí atx̱ʼax̱éedli kʼidéin aax̱ xásh, téix̱ sákw.
Example.Translation: Cut the trimming off of the deer meat well for the broth.

Definition.Definition: O be meaty, muscular, have lots of flesh

Grammar.Text: Used as a noun in compounds and in the %i_ yáx̱ yatee%i colour construction.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘each swan is white’.

Definition.Definition: Whitehorse, the largest city in the Yukon

Grammar.Text: Arguably an adjective + noun phrase rather than a noun + noun compound. The same applies to other %idleit + _%i compounds listed here.

Encyclopedia.Text: The English name, from whence the Tlingit name is derived, comes from the White Horse Rapids which are now submerged under Lake Schwatka.
Does not imply a specific nationality, but American and/or Canadian are usually assumed.

Example.Example: Dleit ḵáach awliyéx̱ wé x̱ʼéi shadagutx̱i lítaa.

Grammar.Text: The other literal translation ‘snow bear’ is equally acceptable.

Encyclopedia.Text: Tlingit people were traditionally unfamiliar with the living polar bear since they lived outside of its range and probably only very rarely travelled to the Arctic, however polar bear furs would have occasionally been available through traditional trade networks. The name is trivially obvious to construct, but it may have not become well known until after European contact.

Lemma.Etymology: unclear, perh. < CJ %ipuš(puš)%i < CJ %ipus(pus)%i < Eng. %ipuss%i or poss. %ipussy-puss%i; initial Tlingit %id%i is unexplained

Definition.Definition: Domestic cat, by extension any small or large feline

Encyclopedia.Text: Although the domestic cat is an entirely European introduction, it has become quite popular among Tlingits over the centuries. Many people keep a cat at their fish camps to control the small rodent population, and some will even regularly bring their cats aboard boats. Black cats are not seriously considered unlucky. Allergy to cats is not uncommon.

Specifically the black cottonwood which grows in river bottoms and other disturbed ground. Rare to nonexistent on the islands, but found along most of the continental coast and up the river valleys. Cottonwood forms the primary tree along much of the Chilkat River, and specimens can be extraordinarily tall and wide – one was measured as 31 m (101 ft) tall and 9.9 m (32.5 ft) around. Notorious for its ‘snow in summer’ when the tree sheds its fluffy seeds which cause allergic reactions in some people. The wood is poor and tends to split and warp; it is useful for firewood after a long drying period but it burns very rapidly. The inner bark is edible but poor and rather bitter, and was only used as a food of last resort. The bark has fairly high levels of salicin (similar to aspirin) and is sometimes used like willow bark for various medicines. The sap is quite sticky and was sometimes used in the past as a glue or caulk. The most important use of cottonwood trees traditionally was in making the cottonwood canoe described below.

Definition.Definition: Dugout canoe made from a cottonwood log

Encyclopedia.Text: These somewhat disposable canoes were made by Tlingits who had traveled inland on trading missions. They were hollowed out but not steam spread unlike the more important canoes made from conifer woods. They were often fairly crude and handled poorly, as attested by comments from early European explorers. Nevertheless, Tlingits were recorded as having sold or traded them to Athabaskans. After coming back down to the coast in one, the cottonwood canoe might be discarded or given to children.
Traditionally a pole-ladder made from steps hewn into a log.

Example.Translation: That is what people made into a ladder.

Grammar.Text: The long vowel form is the older style of spelling, though it may sometimes be used emphatically. The actual vowel has variable length, so that people may pronounce it either short or long.

Definition.Definition: Meaningless nominal base used as a host for postpositional suffixes

Grammar.Text: Postpositions cannot be attached directly to pronouns. Instead, this meaningless base %iee%i follows the possessive form of a pronoun and acts as the host for postposition attachment. The resulting forms have varying tone and are somewhat irregular phonologically. The bare form, which is rare, has low tone.

Definition.Definition: At, on, in, by, of, for

Grammar.Text: The locative suffix %i-ʼ%i attached to the meaningless postposition attachment base %iee%i.

Example.Example: Ax̱ sáni hás, áwu tsú tléixʼ ax̱ kaani yán, tóoxʼ áyá tuwanook, yi ée sh danóogu, tóoxʼ.
Example.Translation: My paternal uncles, there also my brothers-in-law, inside we feel it, the feeling in you, inside.

Example.Example: Dei chʼa chʼáakw áwé hasdu ée antulaxáchch, yá yi aat hás, yi éesh hás.
Example.Translation: Already long ago we were despairing of them (returning), these your paternal aunts, your fathers.

Definition.Comment: specifically the material and not the ceremonial item %itináa%i

Encyclopedia.Text: Traditionally obtained in trade from the Ahtna people of the Copper River valley; now largely from commercial sources. Frequently used for art, jewelry, and ceremonial objects such as daggers.

Lemma.Comment: Also occurs as low tone %ieen%i (q.v.), apparently without any semantic difference.

Grammar.Text: Combination of %iee%i and the instrumental suffix %i-n%i. The latter is used independently in restricted contexts, and otherwise %iéen%i is the default form for instrumental marking.

Lemma.Etymology: from %i√.i%i ‘cook’ and uncert. suffix %i-wu%i, perh. PT %iʔim-ÿi%i ‘cook-%spss%s’?

Encyclopedia.Text: Traditionally made of crossed sticks, with fish fillets or strips laid out flat on it for drying. Compare modern smokehouse racks which serve the same purpose when used without smoking. As such, smokehouse racks may be called %iéinaa%i as well.

Definition.Comment: so defined once in Leer’s notes, but may be a mistranslation

VerbTheme.Notes: Forms other than negative imperfective are unattested.

VerbForm.Gloss: he doesn’t move, he is motionless

VerbTheme.Notes: Forms other than negative imperfective are unattested.

Example.Example: Wé x̱ʼagáaxʼ daakahídi gaawú iḵnáachʼ teen wududliyéx̱.
Example.Translation: That church’s bell is made of brass.
You went through a hard time.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘we worked after time’.

Definition.Definition: An hour, an hour’s time, the space of an hour

Encyclopedia.Text: Meaning is largely as for English ‘duck’, covering all duck-like members of Anatidae but excluding geese and swans. May include other duck-like species outside Anatidae but this has not been investigated. Sea ducks are not considered separately from other ducks except at the species level, and on the coast ‘freshwater’ ducks are indeed likely to be found in salt water regardless of species disposition. Ducks are still hunted for food by some, but are not particularly prized. Eggs were also gathered and eaten, though this is not common today. The migratory behaviour of some duck species are noted in the passage of seasons, and the daily behaviour of ducks is sometimes commented on by elders.

Grammar.Text: From an unknown root %i√sʼa⁽ʼ⁾ch%i.

Lemma.Comment: Leer lists an alternative glottalized root %i√gaʼw%i but examples are lacking. The themes listed here as active might be motion verbs instead.

Example.Translation: A dog barked at him; it was really loud.

Definition.Definition: O be loud voiced, have a loud voice

Example.Translation: When he is loud his paternal aunt sends him outside.

Example.Example: Aanḵaawu G̱eeyxʼ áwé has saligaaw ḵúnáx̱ wé kag̱eet.
Example.Translation: In Ankau Bay they’re really loud, those loons.

Definition.Definition: O be loud voiced, have a loud voice
O be irritatingly insistent, complain loudly or tediously

Example.Translation: He’s going to fight to the end.
Place where there has been war (fighting).
They will take to fighting with each other.

Definition.Definition: S fight for N, defend N

Example.Example: Yú keitl tlein choosh káx̱ ḵuwdligaaw.

Lemma.Comment: Only one theme known, apparently a motion verb.

VerbTheme.Notes: No other forms attested.

Definition.Definition: S go noisily to N, storm off to N

Lemma.Etymology: < CJ %ikinǯúčman%i ‘English; Canadian’ < Eng. %iKing George%i + %iman%i; folk etymology derives the Tlingit from Eng. %iKing George One%i but the earliest possible King George would be the George III.
Lemma.Comment: Also %iKinjuchwáan%i, %iKinjichwáan%i, %iGinjeechwáan%i, etc. May also have final low tone rather than high.

Encyclopedia.Text: Not usually applied to First Nations people, who are instead distinguished by their ethnic or cultural affiliations. This sense covers white Anglophone Canadians by default, but may sometimes be extended to other groups including Francophones and various “visible minorities”.

This was the older definition dating back to the 19th century when Canada was governed by London. After Canadian independence the above sense came to predominate, but there are some cases where the older ‘English, British’ meaning is not differentiated from the newer ‘Canadian’ meaning, such as in %iGinjuchwaan xʼóowu%i below.
As with %iGinjuchwáan%i, this may refer to the English people or the United Kingdom but more typically applies only to Canadians.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘Canadian’s/English’s blanket’; locally in Eng. just ‘Hudson Bay’ as a single word /%pˌhʌd.sənˈbei̯%p/

Encyclopedia.Text: The iconic point blanket manufactured and distributed by the Hudson’s Bay Company of Canada, formerly of England. Usually applies to the multistripe (red, yellow, green, indigo) pattern of blanket, but may also be used for any of the other colours that HBC has produced over the years. Hudson Bay blankets are still widely recognized and highly prized in the Tlingit community. Traditionally they were worn like other blankets, but today they are mostly only found in the home as bedding, or on display folded on the back of a couch or chair. They are symbols of great wealth and generosity when given as potlatch gifts, which happens rarely. Clothes are and were not normally made from them, unlike among indigenous peoples to the east. Pendleton Mills of Oregon manufactures a very similar pattern of blanket under the ‘Glacier Blanket’ name which is also lumped together with true HBC blankets under this term in Tlingit.

Definition.Definition: Sugpiaq or Chugachmiut, indigenous inhabitants of Prince William Sound and the southeastern Kenai Peninsula
Alutiiq, indigenous inhabitants of the southeastern Alaska Peninsula, the Kodiak Islands, and the southern Kenai Peninsula

Encyclopedia.Text: Some speakers lump the Alutiiq together with the Sugpiaq so that all are considered a single ethnicity. Others lump the Alutiiq together with the Aleut (%iAna.óot%i).

Definition.Definition: causation, means for existence or occurrence, chain of events
Portage, passage across a point of land

Encyclopedia.Text: As implied by the term, oak was unknown to the Tlingit before European contact. Garry oak grows on the southeastern end of Vancouver Island and hence may have occasionally been obtained by trade before contact, but there is no evidence for this.

Definition.Definition: Eyak, indigenous inhabitants of the mouth of the Copper River and adjacent coastline to the east
Sugpiaq or Chugachmiut, indigenous inhabitants of Prince William Sound and the southeastern Kenai Peninsula

Encyclopedia.Text: This meaning seems to have ironically arisen by confusion between the Eyak and their neighbours and bitter enemies.

Lemma.Comment: Inland dial. has %ibátaa%i instead.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*gʷeˀł%i < %i*gʷayʔ(a)ł%i <? %i*gʷay̓ał%i; widespread on northern Northwest Coast and of uncertain ultimate origin, cf. Haida %igʷaʔał%i ~ %igʷaːł%i, C. Tsim. & Nis. %igʷéʔ(e)ł%i, Wit. %igʷéʔəł%i, Sek. %igʷèl%i, Eyak %igeːł%i, Aht. %igeł%i, Tah. %igʷeːł%i, etc. Eyak, Tah., and Aht. prob. borrowed through Tlingit, the latter perhaps via Eyak.

Grammar.Text: Possibly calqued from English ‘sack’, but equally an original metaphor.
A phrasal compound and not a morphological compound because the high tone in %ikashóokʼ%i is not neutralized.

Encyclopedia.Text: Refers to the electric heating pad used for relieving pain through diathermy. The term %ikashóokʼ%i here can be interpreted as referring to either ‘electricity’ or to ‘cramp’.

Lemma.Etymology: < CJ %ibit%i ‘dime’ & 19th cen. Eng. %ibit%i ‘one-eighth dollar’ but early 20th cen. ‘dime’

Lemma.Comment: Both verb themes contain a thematic irrealis %iu-%i prefix which is obscured in perfective forms but does appear in the imperfectives.

Definition.Definition: S be shy, bashful toward O
S feel uneasy, not okay with O
O be shy to ask, speak about N

Grammar.Text: The PP adjunct is obligatory and refers to the situation or entity being asked or spoken about, but it often appears simply as a pronoun whose referent is left to context. It is unclear when %iN-xʼ%i (or %iN-ʼ%i) is used and when %iN-x̱%i is used, but both seem to occur for a single speaker.

Example.Translation: He is shy to ask you.
Maybe he is afraid to ask about it.
Example.Comment: Dubitative %igwál%i with irrealis %i-ʼ%i stem variation.
Perfective + prohibitive.
Repetitive imperfective + prohibitive.

Example.Translation: He would have been afraid to ask.

Lemma.Comment: The variation between %ig̱aa%i and %ig̱áa%i is unexplained.

Example.Translation: It’s big enough, it’s sufficiently large.

Grammar.Text: Perfective + prohibitive, with negation for the prohibitive coming from %il%i.

Naish (1966: 8) and Story (1966: 29) labeled this ‘objective’, Leer (1991: 33) ‘vicinitative’; Boas (1917: 102) glossed this as ‘on account of, for a purpose’ and Swanton (1911: 194) glossed it as ‘for’.

Example.Translation: They searched for her, that girl.
He went inside for his book.
You came to help for me.

Example.Example: X̱áatg̱aa naa.ádi, naa.átch yú xóots ḵwáani.
Example.Translation: They’re going for fish, those brown bears are always going.
Write me a little letter for that thing.
We’re going berry picking, for mountain ash berries.

Example.Example: Wé du tuwáa sigóowu g̱áach aawa.oo.
Example.Translation: She bought the rug that she wanted.

Encyclopedia.Text: The pre-European variety is now lost, but historical documents attest to the Tlingit growing a variety that was probably related to %iN. quadrivalvis%i found around the Columbia River and most likely traded from there. The original consumption method of chewing with lime has died out, but modern commercial tobacco smoking and chewing is a major public health problem in the Tlingit community. Tobacco is still used ritually in the modern era, usually employing commercial rolling tobacco or broken cigarettes. When killerwhales are encountered, tobacco is given to them as a propitiation by throwing it out onto the water. By extension, tobacco is also sprinkled on people wearing killerwhale-related regalia during dances or on anyone performing a killerwhale dance. Distribution of tobacco is a part of the “tobacco” or “smoke” ceremony which today functions essentially as a planning meeting immediately before a potlatch. Tobacco may also be sprinkled on the water when passing a shaman’s grave or when passing some other important location. Tobacco is worn as an amulet by some, blessed by various rituals and believed to either bring luck or avert spiritual harm; in such contexts it may be mixed with other plants or with bits of metal or other spiritually powerful substances.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*ɢaχ%i; prob. < PND %i*ɢaχ%i ‘rabbit’ > Eyak %iɢaχ%i ‘rabbit’, PA %i*ɢaχ%i ‘rabbit’, but possibly borrowed from an Ath. lg., though current Tlingit neighbours lack uvulars except for Ahtna

Encyclopedia.Text: Hares and rabbits are technically distinct, with only hares being native to the region; newborn rabbits are hairless and blind, whereas newborn hares are furred with open eyes. The two animals are rarely distinguished in English locally, and are not distinct at all in Tlingit, so this term can cover all Leporidae. The local species is the snowshoe hare %iL. americanus%i, with the subspecies most probably being %iL. a. dalli%i; this is the same subspecies De Laguna (1972: 38) gives as %iL. a. macfarlani%i, and a specimen collected from Carcross by Osgood in 1899 can be found in the Smithsonian (no. USNM 98956). Snowshoe hares range up to around 50 cm (20 in) in total length and weigh up to 2 kg (5 lbs). During winter the hare’s coat is white except for blackish ear tips, and in summer the coat is brown with white underneath. They are mostly nocturnal with some activity at dawn and dusk, and do not hibernate. They sleep in small depressions and natural shelters, and do not dig burrows nor build nests. Snowshoe hares are fairly common in Inland Tlingit country, but rare on the coast except in certain locations near mainland rivers. MacDonald & Cook (1996: 576) report snowshoe hares as documented in the Chilkat Valley, at Dyea near Skagway, occasionally in the lower Taku River valley, and perhaps around the mouth of the Stikine River. De Laguna (1972: 38) also reports them in the Yakutat area and up the Alsek and Tatshenshini Rivers. MacDonald & Cook (1996: 576) find that hares were introduced to Douglas Island from the Haines area in the early 20th century and probably spread from there to the Juneau mainland. Hares from Washington were introduced to Pt. Retreat (Admiralty I.), Otstoia Island (Peril Str.), and Smeaton Island (Behm Canal), but these are presumed to have died out. Another transplantation of hares from near Anchorage was at Cape Island (P.o.W. I.) and at Village Island (Zimovia Str.), but these were also considered to be failures. Rabbits have very little presence in Tlingit culture; Emmons & de Laguna (1991: 136) offer only one mention: “The rabbit, %ikuh%i [i.e. %ig̱áx̱%i], was rare, and was not considered”. De Laguna (1972) provides slightly more, noting that a %iLukaax̱.ádi%i shaman was called %iG̱áx̱ Tlein%i ‘Big Rabbit’ (p. 38), that hares recently came down the Alsek River (p. 367), and that they are mentioned in passing in one version of the Raven Steals Daylight story (p. 862).

Traditionally obtained from meteorites and as ‘drift iron’ from shipwrecks before European contact. Possibly some was also obtained by trade routes from Siberia. Highly prized during the early post-contact period. Has connotations of firmness and reliability. Feared by %ikooshdaaḵáa%i ‘land otter men’ and hence used as a magical amulet to defend against them; still carried by some Tlingits along with other spiritual ‘medicine’ amulets like tobacco (%ig̱ánch%i) and devil’s club (%isʼáxtʼ%i).

Lemma.Comment: All themes based on this root are motion themes and hence are built with various motion derivations. Occasionally the subject intransitive themes are instead object intransitives for some speakers.

Grammar.Text: This has the motion derivation %iN-{t,x̱,dé} (∅; -h Rep)%i meaning ‘arriving at, coming to N’.

Definition.Definition: N (animate) want, have craving, need for S
Definition.Comment: usu. body function or other physical necessity

Grammar.Text: This meaning developed out of a metaphoric notion of bodily urges moving invisibly into the person’s experience. Derivations with particular incorporated alienable nouns are given below; all use the same %iN-{t,x̱,dé} (∅; -h Rep)%i motion derivation as with this theme.

Example.Translation: I wanted (had the urge) to laugh.
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘laughter came invisibly to me’.

Definition.Definition: N want sex, be(come) sexually aroused
N want something hot to drink
N be(come) thirsty, need to drink

Example.Example: Tléil gé i éet shakux wuhaa?
Cháanwaan atx̱aayí x̱wax̱aayéedáx̱ tsu ax̱ éet yaan uháaych.
Example.Translation: I always get hungry again after having eaten Chinese food.

Definition.Definition: S move out into the open, emerge

Example.Example: Gági uwaháa du waḵsheeyéexʼ Chʼáakʼ Ḵuyéik.
Example.Translation: The Eagle Spirit came out before his eyes.

Definition.Definition: S move around invisibly at N

Grammar.Text: The ‘perambulative’ motion derivation used with this theme, %iN-t (na; —)%i has no repetitive imperfective form nor any other basic imperfective.

Example.Translation: The Mosquito Spirit Mask used to move about on its own.

Definition.Definition: S be missing, disappear from N
S (pain, spot, dirt) be gone from N

Example.Translation: The paint on it has disappeared.

Definition.Definition: N lose desire, urge for S

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘sleep move away from one’s face’

Grammar.Text: Note that the %iyaax̱%i form from %iÿá-dáx̱%i is not related to the preverb %iÿaax̱=%i ‘embarking’ which is used in a %ig̱a%i-conjugation motion derivation. The form %iyaatx̱%i also occurs.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘time is coming up toward winter’.

Example.Example: Aadé yaa ḵugahéich, yá aag̱áa adusg̱eiwú yé
Example.Translation: It will be coming, this time when they go seining.

Example.Example: De wa.é áwé, i éet ḵoowaháa.
Example.Translation: Hey you, it’s your turn already.

Definition.Definition: O be clearly visible, obvious (at N)

Grammar.Text: Only occurs in negative forms; literally something like ‘not move invisibly’. Sometimes the negative particle %itléil%i is missing, but the meaning remains the same. Note that the %iga%i-conjugation prefix appears in all forms.

Example.Translation: Things are easily seen in there.

Definition.Comment: by boat or vehicle, to known destination

Lemma.Comment: Mostly occurs with %ika-%i but some themes have %iÿa-%i or both instead.

Example.Translation: When it becomes fall they dig up potatoes.

Example.Example: Yú yaa kanduhéin yé áwé a taadé wdzigeet.
Example.Translation: He fell into the place that was being dug.

Grammar.Text: The intransitive counterpart to the parent theme above.

VerbTheme.Notes: The location adjunct often appears with no postposition, is this a ditransitive? Might be a motion derivation.

Definition.Definition: S smear, rub O on N

Example.Example: Ax̱ tláa ḵaa daneisʼí ax̱ daa yoo akaawahaa.
Example.Translation: My mother rubbed my skin with liniment.
He’s rubbing medicine into his skin.

Definition.Definition: S push, shove, shovel O (pl.) toward N
Definition.Comment: object is an undifferentiated mass e.g. dirt, mud, snow, berries, toys, seaweed, forming a pile at N

Example.Translation: Push the sand over to the side.

VerbTheme.Notes: check if ∅ or ∅-ÿ

Definition.Definition: S bring O out into the open horizontally or in masses, to form a mass or pile
S dig up, unearth, mine O

Example.Example: Tle hít tuwán áwé kóoḵ kei has akaawaháa.
Example.Translation: Right next to the house they dug up a pit.
He sold the gold that he mined.

VerbTheme.Notes: Figure out exactly what N is here.

Grammar.Text: The inalienable noun %ikáa%i (%i–ká%i ‘horiz. surface’ + %i-ʼ%i ‘locative’) does not have a possessor, so any noun preceding it does not possess it. Instead %ikáa%i behaves like an adverb.

Example.Example: I atgas.eeyí gwaa gé i jeeyís káa yoo kakwḵaháa?
Example.Translation: Shall I stir your cooking for you?

Definition.Definition: S spread out O (butter, lard, jelly, paste) on N

Example.Example: Sh yadaa yoo kaydahá wé léix̱ʼw.
Example.Translation: Spread it all over your (pl.) faces, that red ochre.

Definition.Definition: S take away, remove O from N

Example.Translation: The south wind is clearing away the clouds (from the sky).
Remove it from in front of it.

Definition.Definition: S bring, take O (mass, group) to N

Example.Translation: Long ago they used to plant rutabaga.

Example.Example: Du hídi gukshutú, áa akaawahaa wé ḵʼeikaxwéin.
Example.Translation: At the corner of her house, there she planted those flowers.
He’s planting it there, in the ground.

VerbTheme.Notes: Check impfv type. How is this with [s] different from %iakaawaháa%i with [∅]?

Definition.Comment: N&S say ‘dig deep’ but this is not clear

Definition.Definition: S spread out O (mass or pl. objs., e.g. seaweed, berries, rugs) along N
S spread out O (mass or pl. objs., e.g. seaweed, berries, rugs) along N
S spread out O on ground

Example.Translation: He spread out the seaweed on the ground.

Definition.Definition: Digging stick, digging tool, tool used for planting
Skin scraper for graining and dehairing.

Lemma.Notes: Only perfective examples for these themes, so ephemera still unclear. Leer gives ‘∅·’ i.e. ∅-ÿ for a few of them; all could be ∅-ÿ but only ∅ is certain.

Definition.Definition: O fit at N, O move into exact position at N

Example.Translation: I didn’t believe that it (jigsaw piece) would fit there.

Example.Example: Chʼa aadé yeeyaḵaayyé yáx̱ áa uwaháa.
Example.Translation: It fits like the way you (pl.) said.

Example.Example: Aadé ash saheiyi yé áa uwaháa.
Example.Translation: What he intended came to pass.

Definition.Definition: S make O fit at N

Example.Comment: Meaning ‘he did what he had been planning to do’.

Example.Translation: He’s trying to fit them together.

Definition.Definition: S let O go away in the manner of N

Example.Example: Ash wutlʼeedí, chʼa aadé dé awsiháa.
Example.Translation: When she left him, he just let her go.

Definition.Definition: S come upon, come across, discover O at N

Example.Translation: We came across a brown bear in its den.

Definition.Definition: S come across O in the act of N
S catch O in the act of N
S come upon O doing N

Example.Translation: I caught him doing it, after that he grabbed it.

Example.Example: A káa daak jiwtooliháa at gas.eeyí.
Example.Translation: We came across him cooking for himself.
I brought him along to there.

Lemma.Comment: All themes contain the incorporated inalienable noun %isa-%i ~ %ise-%i ‘voice’. Imperfectives have the irregular stem %i–héi%i, irrealis %i–hé%i. Leer erroneously lists this root as CVʰ but with e.g. %i-ch%i the stem is %i–héich%i and not %i–heich%i; there may be unreported dialect differences however.

VerbTheme.Notes: Need to investigate distribution of %isa-%i vs. %ise-%i. Also check other modes for occurrence of %i–héi%i stem.

Definition.Definition: S be willing for O, to do O
S agree to O, be agreeable about O
S want to O, want for O to be so

Grammar.Text: At least in the realis perfective mode the incorporated noun %isa-%i ‘voice’ may occur as %ise-%i instead, thus %ise-ÿu-ÿa-%i → %iseiwa-%i instead of %isa-ÿu-ÿa-%i → %isaawa-%i. The manner argument indicated by %iyéi=%i is the manner in which the object argument O is desired to be.

Example.Translation: My mother is willing for me (to go, to talk, etc.).
I want for you to have this book.
Whoever wants it, raise your hand.
I’m willing to give a report.
Example.Comment: Leer also notes %i… yéi nḵwasaneiyí%i as an alternative.

Example.Translation: He’s willing to let him marry her.
He was willing to go / he wanted him to go.
Example.Notes: Check the two translations, one may be inaccurate.

Definition.Definition: S want to be rid of O
S want O to disappear or die
Definition.Notes: This sense is questionable, only documented from a single example by Leer.

Example.Translation: He wanted to get rid of him.
He wants to be like him.
He wanted his grandparent by his side.

VerbTheme.Notes: Needs more investigation and examples. Probably %ig̱a%i-conjugation but this is uncertain.

Example.Example: Du tóonáx̱ kínde ḵusayahéi du héex̱w.
Example.Translation: His witchcraft wants to reveal itself.

Lemma.Notes: Themes are probably eventive but this needs to be checked.

Definition.Comment: may be with intent for harm

Definition.Definition: S fight (unarmed), wrestle, box with N

Example.Translation: I’m going to fight with him.

Lemma.Etymology: Leer suggests a possible relationship with Eyak %iʔaˀ%i ‘be above a certain size’ and PA %i*łaˑŋʸ%i ‘be many’ > Nav. %iłą́%i, Hup. %iłaˑn%i, Koy. %ilɔni%i, Car. %iłai%i, etc.; PA may have merged a %ił-%i classifier with the root, so perh. PND %i*ʔaŋˀ%i > PT %i*haʰŋ%i maybe with %i*-ŋ%i preserved as the stv. impfv. suffix.
Lemma.Comment: Apparently the only root in Tlingit that has %i-n%i stative imperfective forms for its themes. Note that the progressive with %i-n%i is also long and high, clearly implying that this is an open root and not one ending with %in%i.

Grammar.Text: A wide variety of forms exist for the stative imperfective of this theme because of its frequency in speech. Examples include %isheiyadihéin%i, %isheedihéin%i, %ishaydéin%i, and %isheedhéin%i. Other conjugations vary somewhat less due to their lower frequencies of use.

Example.Translation: There are going to be many of us.
There are a lot of schoolchildren in Yakutat.
There are a lot of cows in that farmer’s possession.
There are getting to be many.

Grammar.Text: A somewhat unusual form using %iḵu-%i instead of indef. hum. obj. %iḵaa-%i ‘someone; people’.

Example.Translation: There used to be many people at %iGaawtʼaḵ.aan%i.

Grammar.Text: Like the verb above that this is based on, this adverb has a variety of forms such as %isheedahéindéin%i and %ishidéindéin%i.

Example.Comment: Note %idu daati wduwatée%i < %idu daateeyí wduwatée%i, cf. %i√tiʰ%i ‘handle’.

Example.Translation: There are quite a few herring.

Example.Example: Haa tláa hás ḵútlʼgig̱áa has na.átch hasdu ḵʼeikaxwéini yís.
Example.Translation: Our mothers send us for soil for their flowers.
We need to leave from here right now.

Lemma.Comment: An excrescent %in%i appears with the allative postposition %i-dé%i, so %ihaandé%i; people with this form reject %ihaadé%i, though some have regularized away the %in%i and hence permit %ihaadé%i.

Grammar.Text: Normally occurs with postpositions, esp. %i-dé%i. Contrast with first person plural postpositional pronoun which requires the meaningless attachment base %i=ee%i, eg. %ihaa=ee-dé%i ‘toward us’.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘your hand hither!’.

Example.Example: Haandé wé ách at dusx̱a át.

Grammar.Text: Group E1 preverb. Has the form %ihaat=%i with punctual %i-t%i, %ihaax̱=%i with pertingent %i-x̱%i, and %ihaadé=%i with allative %i-dé%i. Part of the motion derivation %ihaa-{t,x̱,dé}=%i (∅; %i-h%i Rep) ‘coming here’. Sometimes occurs with excrescent %in%i for some people, but generally not.

Example.Translation: Whenever you make faces you always look disgraceful.

Encyclopedia.Text: Said when casually requesting a physical object from someone. Not used if the giver is already in the process of giving the object. Can be perceived as rude depending on the context, not usually used in formal situations.

Definition.Comment: used to get a person’s attention and encourage them

Example.Example: Háakw, dé wa.é áwé i éet ḵoowaháa, Sḵéitʼ.
Example.Translation: Go for it, it’s already come to your turn, %iSḵéitʼ%i.

Encyclopedia.Text: Leer notes that this “always involves yelling and usually stamping of feet”.

Example.Translation: He said %iháakw%i to people (encouraged them to do their best).

Definition.Definition: S come out and dance to encourage O

Encyclopedia.Text: Leer describes %idaak kawduwaháakw%i as meaning “they got out and danced their hardest (as at a peace ceremony) like they were going to war”.

Refers to when a crowd encourages a person who is either being killed or set free. By extension, when a person is engaged in some activity that once involved killing of slaves, such as setting up a gravestone or starting to build a tribal house.

Example.Translation: His relatives gave a good-bye shout to him as he was about to be killed.
He didn’t have to die but he had built himself up to it so he just %iháakw%ied out.

Encyclopedia.Text: Describes how drummers and singers encourage a group of dancers to come onstage (formerly to enter a house).

Example.Translation: People were encouraging them to come out.

Definition.Comment: used to get a person’s attention and encourage them

Definition.Definition: Give me, give us, gimme, hand over

Grammar.Text: Morphologically this appears to be the adverb %ihaa(n)%i ‘here’ with the allative postposition %i-dé%i ‘toward’, but it functions as a predicate and thus occurs without a verb.

Example.Example: Háasʼ du éet yéi uwanéi yá yagiyee.
Example.Translation: He has had vomiting happen today.

Grammar.Text: Only the imperfective form is documented; may be imperfective-only. The %i-k(w)%i is probably the repetitive suffix, but it is apparently lexicalized. Choice of rounded vs. unrounded form is probably idiolectal.

Definition.Definition: O show signs of Parkinsons or similar neuromuscular disease

Encyclopedia.Text: Typically used as a substrate for herring spawn.

Johnny Marks notes “where a certain part of the body has fallen asleep, usually happens to a person with shamanistic background”. Naish & Story say “these sensations may be attributed to being grabbed by a ghost”. Leer elaborates “(body part) feels like it has become numb or is being tickled or has water running over it” and “kind of vague sensation attributed to spirit activity – often happens to a person with shamanistic background”.

Example.Translation: My cheek feels like water is running down it.

Grammar.Text: Documented only in Tongass Tlingit, so possibly restricted to that dialect.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘I’m just standing at a place’.
Lit. ‘he’s standing at the (front) end (of the line, etc.)’.
Said of someone expected to be unable to stand, e.g. baby or bedridden person. Lit. ‘just him, he stands up’.

Example.Translation: He tries to stand up from there (but can’t).
I stood up so I could say thank you.
He exchanged places with us, going outside.
Example.Comment: Lit. something like ‘he stood up switching us, outsideward’, so ‘he stood up so that we could sit down, and he went outside’.

Example.Example: Ḵux̱ idahán sʼé, i een at kanḵaneegéet áwé.
Example.Translation: Stop, so I can tell you something.

Example.Example: Tléil de du x̱ʼayeexʼ ḵux̱ ux̱dahánch.
Example.Translation: I never stop to listen to him.

Example.Example: A náḵ ḵux̱ wudihán du l.ushkʼéiyi.
Example.Translation: He turned back from his sin.
I’m going to stand by the door.

Example.Example: Tléil aadé a yáa yan ḵwahani yé.
Example.Translation: There’s no way I can stand it.

Example.Example: Ḵaan kageitxʼ yan uwahán, wé yoo x̱ʼatánk een.
Example.Translation: He stood against people with that speech.
Example.Comment: Leer notes this as meaning ‘preaching what he doesn’t practice’.
Lit. ‘he stood around it’.

Example.Example: I yoo x̱ʼatángi káa yan hán!
A yaadé nagú; a tuwánxʼ yan hán.
Example.Translation: Walk to the face of it; stand beside it.
He cut the seal blubber into strips.
Example.Comment: Epiaspectual %i-t%i from repetitive imperfective with ‘serial’ %i-t%i.

Example.Translation: He cut a fringe into the edge of the blanket.

Example.Example: Wé sʼisaa yei akagux̱saháan, wé a wán.
Example.Translation: He’s going to cut a fringe in that cloth, its edge.

Example.Example: Lʼeix̱ kakʼoodásʼi a kóon yéi kdus.hánch.
Example.Translation: A fringe is put on the hem of a dance hirt.
Tanned hides were cut into strips for rope.
Her boat drifted to a reef.

Example.Example: Tleidahéen áwé Yaakwdáatt aa wlihásh wé kanóoxʼ.
Example.Translation: Once some turtle floated to Yakutat.

Definition.Definition: N gain possession, control of O
Definition.Comment: presupposes no other person having O; lit. ‘O drift into N’s possession’

Example.Translation: It drifted ashore along a good sandy beach.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘it floated up’.

Definition.Definition: O float, drift out to sea

Example.Example: Du jináḵ daak wulihásh wé chʼáalʼ.
Example.Translation: The willow drifted out away from him.
The leaf floated around the end of the water.

Definition.Definition: S abandon, let go of O
S let N take over O
O be buoyant, O be floatable, able to float

Example.Translation: He keeps vomiting because of his headache.

Example.Example: Chʼa daa sáwé tle ash ulhásʼjin.
Example.Translation: Just anything used to make him vomit.

Lemma.Comment: Leer explains this as meaning “with someone else or alone, with arms extended down, or over back/shoulder, or on head”.

Definition.Definition: S carry heavy O to N

Example.Translation: Lug that big pot here, you guys.
They are carrying a dead body.

Definition.Definition: S carry heavy O toward N

Example.Translation: They’ve already lugged it off toward there.

Definition.Definition: S carry heavy O around N

Example.Example: Lḵwakanáax̱ʼ áwé át anas.hátch wé du gishoo taayí.
Example.Translation: He just packs his bacon around for nothing.

Definition.Definition: S lug O off of, away from N

Example.Translation: They tried to carry off that boat.

Example.Example: Séew daak gux̱satáan shákdé; wé x̱aanásʼ kasahát xwaasdáa teen.
Example.Translation: It’s probably going to rain; cover the drying rack with canvas.

Encyclopedia.Text: Johnny Marks notes: “to feel about – not really knowing where to place hand; also to grope in dark”.

Example.Translation: She’s feeling around on his head (e.g. for lice); she’s fondling his hair.
He’s feeling around on his body.
He drove them into the cow barn.

Example.Comment: Conventional term for the biblical “Promised Land”. Note reduced stem.

Example.Example: Nax̱duhéinit asayahéi, ách áwé chʼa áa altín.
Example.Translation: He’d like someone (else) to claim it, that’s why he’s just watching it there.

Grammar.Text: Leer relates this to %i√hélʼk%i, apparently by semantic opposition.

Definition.Definition: Cry used by shaman to make fish die.

Grammar.Text: Looks suspiciously like a verb, specifically like an imperfective %iÿi-[−D,l,−I]-√hel-ː%i with second person plural object %iÿi-%i, classifier %ila-%i, and %i-ː%i stem variation. But it is not recognized by any living Tlingit speakers as a verb.
Often negated with %itléil%i, but with essentially the same meaning as the positive form.

Example.Translation: He was clumsy and weak when he grew bigger.

Definition.Definition: O be weak, clumsy in speech

Example.Translation: Don’t ask him to speak, he’s weak in speech.

Grammar.Text: The vowel has variable length, so people may pronounce it short or long. The older spelling is %iee%i.

Example.Translation: Only one is finished cooking yet.

Example.Example: Wé sakwnéin éewu yan g̱a.eet eeg̱áa áwé x̱a.áa.
Example.Translation: I’m sitting waiting for the bread to finish cooking.

Example.Example: X̱ʼáakw x̱ʼúx̱u haa x̱ʼéis sa.í stoox kaanáx̱.
Example.Translation: Cook us some freshwater-marked sockeye soup on the stove.

Example.Example: Wé ḵáa dzískʼw shaayí gangooknáx̱ as.eeyín.
Example.Translation: That man used to cook moose heads by the fire.

Example.Example: Du léelkʼw du x̱'éis at wusi.ée.
Du kéilkʼ du x̱ʼéis at wusi.ée.

Encyclopedia.Text: The Ahtna people were well known to the %iYaakwdáat Ḵwáan%i and to a lesser extent the other northerly %iḵwáan%i. Tlingits traded directly with the Ahtna, travelling to the Copper River and meeting the Ahtna near the mouth. Trade also occurred through Eyak intermediaries.
