The Ahtna were known especially for their copper in the era before European contact, forming the primary source of copper in Tlingit culture, and trade in copper to the south was a major source of wealth for Tlingit people. The name %iIḵkahaa Ḵwáan%i specifically refers to this role of the Ahtna as copper providers in pre-European Tlingit society. The %iKwaashkʼi Ḵwáan%i clan of Yakutat were originally Ahtna, having emigrated to Tlingit country over the glaciers near Mt. St. Elias (%iŸaasʼeitasháa%i) which they claim as %iat.óow%i.

Grammar.Text: Usually used with either %i-dáx̱%i or %i-náx̱%i.

The appearance of %iu-%i in the stative imperfective combined with %i-ÿ%i stem variation makes it look like a perfective %i∅%i-conjugation verb, %ia-u-∅-∅-ÿa-%i → %ioowa-%i and %i∅-u-∅-x̱a-ÿa-%i → %ix̱waa-%i, but it is actually a %ina%i-conjugation stative imperfective. The perfective has %i-h%i stem variation (long and low %i–jee%i in Northern) whereas the stative imperfective has %i-ÿ%i stem variation (long and high %i–jée%i in Northern), so the two can be told apart by stem form independent of other mode morphology.

Example.Translation: I think he is the one who stole it.
He put the coat on him.
Is there seaweed on my teeth?

Grammar.Text: Prefixed with horizontal surface %ika-%i which probably has its ‘small round object’ meaning.
Leer notes %ikahánaa%i in his notes but it is unclear who uses this variant.
Apparently from a phrase like %ikalicháni át%i ‘thing that stinks’, but the reason for this is unclear.

Encyclopedia.Text: The indigenous Sitka mountain-ash is a small deciduous tree or shrub, 1–4 m tall, found throughout %iLingít aaní%i. The young bark is reddish but older bark is grayish-red; both are fairly smooth. The leaves are pinnate, dark green above and pale green beneath, oblong to ovate, and sharply serrated. In the spring it has small white flowers with yellow or white centers in a branched cluster, and it is essentially the only tree in %iLingít Aaní%i that bears obvious flowers. The fruit is a small, red, apple-like pome the size of a blueberry which is inedible for humans but is a favourite of birds. In the winter the fruits may ferment on the tree, and the antics of drunken birds can be entertaining. Mountain-ash is also a favourite browse of deer, and of moose along the continental rivers. The wood works easily and can be used like alder for tool handles and drum sticks, though the small size limits its utility. It is only rarely used for carving. The wood burns quite well but is not used for smoking. Other %iSorbus%i species now found in urban landscaping are referred to by the same name.

Example.Translation: Mountain ash doesn’t grow in Yakutat.

Definition.Definition: Bladder, bodily organ that stores urine
Bladder bone? Perhaps this either refers to the pubic bone or to urinary calculi (bladder stones)

Lemma.Etymology: Unknown, but not borrowed from any other language given the unique %iχʼ⁽ʷ⁾%i phoneme; probably derived from a verb

Encyclopedia.Text: Though bamboo does not grow in %iLingít Aaní%i, Tlingit people were familiar with it from driftwood carried to Alaska by the North Pacific currents. The traditional %iḴaax̱ʼachgóok%i story includes Tlingit men from Sitka stranded on what seems to be a semitropical island, and they collect rainwater from broken bamboo plants as well as other uses.

Example.Example: Chʼu tle wdziḵʼíkʼ áyú yú át ḵu.aa; kaneilx̱ʼú a káa kaawa.aa.
Example.Translation: But it was just dense that thing (island) was; bamboo grew on it.

Example.Example: Yá kʼeeljáach aax̱ wudig̱aalʼixʼi aa kaneilx̱ʼú agoowxʼú áwé shayawlitsʼítʼ héen, séew héeni.
Example.Translation: The stumps of these bamboo ones which were broken off by the storm were filled by water, rain water.

Example.Example: Áxʼ áwé ḵaa jikaawaḵáa wé kaneilx̱ʼú, yaakw yáx̱ kudayatʼ aa déix̱.
Example.Translation: So there he told them to collect those bamboo, two of them as long as the canoe.

Example.Example: Xáanaadé áwé shawdudziyaa wé shayéinaa sákw, kaneilx̱ʼú.
Example.Translation: Toward evening they had anchored with those (things that they had made into) future anchors, bamboos.

Lemma.Etymology: perh. from %ikeitl%i ‘dog’ and %iát%i ‘thing’ or %iÿát%i ‘child’ but suprasegmental properties do not match; this etymology is especially problematic for Tongass and Southern forms

Encyclopedia.Text: Little effort is paid to differences between gull species, so that e.g. the Mew gull (%iL. canus brachyrhynchus%i Richardson 1831), California gull (%iL. californicus%i Lawrence 1854), Herring gull (%iL. smithsonianus%i Coues 1862), and Glaucous-winged gull (%iL. glaucescens%i Naumann 1840) are usually lumped together as a single species, though some elders may distinguish different species on the basis of subtle differences in wing, tail, leg, and beak colour. Gulls are mostly associated with the intertidal environment and especially with garbage because of their habits around human settlements. Gulls are not a very highly esteemed bird, but they do appear in a few myths such as %iAakʼwtaatseen%i / %iShaanyaakʼutlaax̱%i “Salmon Boy / Moldy End”.

Lemma.Etymology: perh. < PND %i*kʸey-ɬ%i ‘bark-er?’, like Ru. лайка ‘hunting dog’ < лаяать ‘to bark’; cf. PA %i*yə-tseː(y)%i ‘to bark’, Eyak %iʔi-kahɬ%i ‘to bark’; the widespread PA %i*ɬəŋʸ(kʼʸeˑ)%i ‘dog’ > Aht. %iɬikʼe%i, Nav. %iɬį́į́ʼ%i, Hup. %iɬiŋkʼ%i, Chp. %iɬį̀%i, etc. is not cognate

Definition.Definition: Domestic dog, applied to all breeds

Encyclopedia.Text: There was an indigenous breed of dog but it has gone extinct. Modern Tlingits own various kinds of dogs, with the Alaskan Husky and German Shepherd being popular, but dog breeding is not a major concern. Dogs are mostly companions today, but many are trained for hunting and guarding remote camps using traditional methods. Dogs may seem feral in village settings but usually residents can ascribe ownership for specific dogs. Some clan names developed from dog names based on teknonymy, for instance %iChánkʼ Éesh%i ‘Little Stink’s Father’ from a dog named %iChánkʼ%i ‘Little Stink’. But dog names, and dogs themselves, are usually private rather than clan property.

Definition.Comment: used as a conventional colour term for ‘yellow’

Encyclopedia.Text: A medium-sized woodpecker, up to 36 cm (14 in) long with a 54 cm (21 in) wingspan. Light brown with black bars speckling the wings and back, a beige to tawny cap, and grey cheeks. Red under the wings and tail with a white rump that is visible in flight. Males have a distinctive red moustache extending back from the base of the beak. The only woodpecker to routinely eat on the ground, typically found probing lawns and forest edges. Their primary foods are ants, other insects, berries, and seeds. They nest mostly in tree cavities but may sometimes be found in cliffside burrows made by other birds like kingfishers. Occasionally a flicker family will take up residence in an older totem pole, this may be tolerated by the Tlingit community or the flickers may be evicted. Most people will chase them out of nests carved into wooden buildings, but otherwise flickers are largely unmolested. They are year-round residents in southern coastal Tlingit country, and are migratory summer residents elsewhere in %iLingít Aaní%i. Flicker tail feathers are stiff, like all woodpeckers being used to prop against trees. The tail feathers are frequently used with sealion whiskers along the edges of %ishakee.át%i head frontlets, among other types of artistic employment. The curved and pointed ends of the tail feathers are said to be the inspiration for the divided U-form in Tlingit art, as found e.g. in the ear designs of animal figures. The %iDaḵlʼaweidí%i clan and the %iNaasdeidí%i clan both use the flicker as a crest, and both clans have houses named %iKóon Hít%i ‘Flicker House’ in %iTaanʼtá Ḵwáan%i and %iKooyú Ḵwáan%i respectively.

Example.Example: Kóon tʼaawú yéi ndu.eich alʼéix̱ yís.
Example.Translation: Flicker feathers are used for dancing.

Encyclopedia.Text: Much has been written about land otters in Tlingit ethnography so that little need be said here. The tongue of a land otter is a major source of shamanic power, and shamans traditionally would have to collect a number (ideally eight) of the tongues in order to gain an appropriate command of the spiritual realm. The land otter men (see below) are fearsome monsters in Tlingit tradition. Consequently even today Tlingits tend to avoid land otters, rarely use their fur, and do not normally employ them much in traditional heraldry (though exceptions exist). Because of their association with the strange and supernatural, the term %ikóoshdaa%i has also become a generic attribute in compounds referring to magical or bizarre things.

Example.Translation: The land otter swam along our beachfront.

Example.Example: Aas tʼéik áwé áa awdlisín wé kóoshdaa.
Example.Translation: It hid behind a tree there, that land otter.

Example.Example: Ax̱ tuyík kóoshdaayí sh tóog̱aa wditee.
Example.Translation: My inner land otter is pleased.
Example.Comment: Said when satisfied after eating.

Encyclopedia.Text: Land otter men are the primary monsters in Tlingit tradition. They wield enormous spiritual power and are hence greatly feared. They “rescue” drowning victims and convert them to land otter men, who themselves later haunt their relatives and attempt to convert them as well. Equation of land otter men to the sasquatch of the southern Northwest Coast is improper because the traditions about them are distinctly different, though some cryptozoologic enthusiasts have made such claims.

Subentry.Comment: Also sometimes a possessive compound %ikóoshdaa náagu%i.

Definition.Definition: Peppermint, spearmint, or other foreign mint
Liniment, any minty (i.e. mentholated) ointment used topically for pain relief

Grammar.Text: In Northern Tlingit there is an irregular first person form %iux̱sikóo%i = %ix̱wasikóo%i ‘I know it’ with an accompanying negative form %itl. ux̱sakú%i = %itl. x̱wasakú%i ‘I don’t know it’. This is firmly documented from Hoonah and Yakutat, but may be more widely distributed. Note that although English ‘know’ is ambitransitive, meaning that it can be used with or without an object, the Tlingit verb is only transitive and hence an object is always presupposed. Thus %itléil x̱wasakú%i means literally ‘I don’t know it’ and not simply ‘I don’t know’.

Encyclopedia.Text: The equivalent to colloquial English ‘I dunno’ is %il x̱waskú%i or %il x̱wskú%i, which can be used in casual situations but can be perceived as rude in more formal environments. For the verb meaning ‘know how’ see %i√guk%i.

Example.Comment: The biblical sense of ‘know’ as ‘have sexual relations with’ is intended according to Leer’s notes. This is a calque from English.

Example.Example: Has g̱aduskóot áwé koogéinaa yéi s aya.óo.
Example.Translation: The sash they wear is how they can be known.

Example.Example: Tléil x̱wasakú «g̱eey kanax̱ ḵutéesʼ» yóo duwasáagu x̱áat.
Example.Translation: I don’t know a fish that people call “looking out across the bay” (ratfish).
He knows it like the palm of his hand.

Definition.Definition: S come to know, learn O

Grammar.Text: This sense applies when the verb is progressive.

Definition.Definition: S make O known to N

Grammar.Text: This is an unusual causative construction lacking any special verb morphology. The subject is the experiencer in the base theme, but in this derived theme the subject is the causer and the oblique %idu ée%i becomes the experiencer.

Example.Example: Hasdu ée ix̱wsikóo … anax̱ tóo has ag̱anookt has isax̱áni.
Example.Translation: I made you known to them … so that they might be aware of your love for them.
He is letting him know about it.
He’s trying to inform her of it.
He’s going to let you know about it.
Example.Comment: Leer’s original translation was backwards.

Definition.Definition: S learn about O from N’s speech

Definition.Comment: in a legal sense, by extension of the basic meaning

VerbTheme.Notes: Need to check other possible modes, subjects, and adjuncts.

Lemma.Etymology: perh. < Eng. %iquarantine%i via some intermediate reanalysis of %ikwáan teen%i, but this is uncertain

Definition.Definition: Raven moiety clan of Yakutat and Kaliakh area

Encyclopedia.Text: A clan of Yakutat (%iYaakwdaat Ḵwáan%i) and the neighbouring Kaliakh area (%iG̱alyáx̱ Ḵwáan%i), descended from Ahtna immigrants who came over the mountains near Mt. St. Elias to the Gulf Coast. The Tlingit placename %iKwáashkʼ%i is the name of a creek (Swanton 1908: 413) borrowed from Eyak %ikʷaːškʼ%i ‘humpback salmon’. De Laguna (1972) reports that they are the same as the %iKʼinéix̱ Ḵwáan%i but Emmons says their old name was “Ta-hane-kwan” when they lived on the Copper River. This latter name might be from %iLdax̱éin%i from Ahtna %iTaghael(den)%i ‘Taral’ according to Leer (cf. the Tlingit clan %iStax̱.ádi%i). Swanton (1909: 347–368) recorded the story of the %iKwáashkʼi Ḵwáan%i clan migration from a Yakutat man he named “Q!âʹdustin”. This latter name might be %iḴʼaawdusteen%i, %iX̱ʼwaadusteen%i, %iḴaadusteen%i, or any of several other variants given Swanton’s transcription. The last form %iḴaadusteen%i would be a name meaning ‘someone is seen’, cf. %i√tin%i.

Lemma.Comment: Only known from the nominalization %ix̱alakʼáchʼ%i ‘porcupine’.
Special plural form %i–kʼátsxʼi%i lacks the %i-kʼu%i, according with the latter being diminutive.

Definition.Definition: O be pointy, have a sharp point, have spikes
O be sharp, have sharp edge
O be have needles, spikes, thorns, be thorny

Example.Translation: A mosquito has a sharp beak.

Definition.Definition: Goodness, abstract property of being good
False huckleberry, mock azalea, rusty menziesia

Grammar.Text: Perhaps extended from the specific sense, or may have been misinterpreted.

Lemma.Comment: Partially variable, usually appears as invariable %i–kʼéi%i but as %i–kʼé%i in irrealis forms, and may be %i–kʼe%i in Southern (and Transitional?) relativized forms. Tongass varies between %i–kʼei%i and %i–kʼe%i. Negative forms (though not necessarily all irrealis forms) often show %ish%i-alternation in the classifier.

VerbTheme.Notes: Verify non-negative progressive.

Example.Translation: Does that seem good to you?

Example.Example: Lʼook kaháagu áyá yakʼéi kanatʼá kanéegwálʼ sákw.
Example.Translation: Coho eggs are good for blueberry %ikanéegwálʼ%i.

Definition.Definition: O be bad, evil, not good
Definition.Comment: negative form of the theme above

Encyclopedia.Text: Some elders consider using this verb theme to be taboo, though others have no such qualms about it.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘is it a bad thing?’ Relativized form.

Example.Example: Tlél ushikʼéiyi aa yoo x̱ʼatánk áwé tsá a.ax̱ji nooch.
Example.Translation: She only ever hears the bad talk.
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘talk that is a bad one’. Relativized form.

Encyclopedia.Text: Leer’s notes say “what the boy was saying when he killed his brother in Ahtena”, so this is may come from the Kwaashkʼi Ḵwáan clan history.

Definition.Definition: Rosehip, fruit of a rose bush

Example.Example: Kʼinchéiyi áwé ax̱ tláa jeeyís x̱waa.oo.
Example.Translation: I bought a rose for my mother.

Definition.Definition: Rosehip, fruit of a rose bush

Grammar.Text: Only used by people who have %ikʼinchéiyi%i as ‘rose’ rather than ‘rosehip’.

Example.Example: Kʼinchéiyi tléig̱u teen wududzi.ée yú kanatʼá.
Example.Translation: They were cooked with rosehips, those blueberries.

Lemma.Etymology: < PND %i*kʼʸa/e⁽⁾qʼʷ%i ‘sticky stuff’; cf. Eyak %itsʼaʼqʼ%i ‘soft feces, diarrhea’, PA %i*tsʼeːqʼ%i ‘glue’

Encyclopedia.Text: Pitch from white spruce trees, imported from the Inland Tlingit or from Athabaskans, was a traditional form of chewing gum. Pitch from Sitka spruce and other conifers was used for waterproofing and as a general adhesive.

Apparently applied due to similarity, since soft lead is similar to hard pitch in texture and malleability. Lead is widely used by Tlingits in the form of fishing weights, though it was unknown before European contact.

Definition.Definition: Lead sinker as attached to a fishing net

Grammar.Text: Not actually an inalienable noun, but treated that way due to the distinct meaning.

Definition.Definition: Soft lead, lead which is malleable without special tools

Encyclopedia.Text: Specifically describes the type of lead that is used for weights in fishing.

Definition.Definition: Lead line of a fishing net

Encyclopedia.Text: Ferns are primarily distinguished on the basis of their edibility, and subtle differences in appearance are mostly ignored. As a consequence, the term %ikʼwálx̱%i refers to any fern that produces an edible fiddlehead in the spring and whose roots and sprouts can be harvested for food. The quintessential examples of %ikʼwálx̱%i are the Northwestern lady fern (%iA. filix-femina%i ssp. %icyclosorum%i), the Northern wood fern (%iD. expansa%i), and the bracken fern (%iP. aquilinum%i var. %ipubescens%i), but speakers apply the same name to different species in different locations depending on local harvesting practices. Generally only pinnate-pinnatifid or bipinnate-pinnatifid ferns are included, so that e.g. the common sword fern (%iPolystichum munitum%i (Kaulf.) C.Presl 1836) is usually excluded. Fiddlehead ferns are eaten for both their spring fiddlehead sprouts as well as dug for their rhizomes. The practice of eating the fiddlehead sprouts may or may not be a modern introduction, but the rhizomes were traditionally collected, steamed or baked, and eaten for their starch before European contact. The rhizomes can be canned in (seal, hooligan, etc.) oil for preservation after cooking, and the sprouts can be pickled or salted and canned for storage.

Definition.Definition: ‘Shield fern’ in Leer’s notes, of undetermined species

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘how big are the eggs?’

Example.Translation: We’re going to Egg Island for bird eggs.

Grammar.Text: This theme is transitive but often the object does not appear, thus making it seem intransitive.

Example.Translation: Geese lay eggs in the bay.
They have already laid eggs now.

Grammar.Text: This theme is truly intransitive, never having an object.

Example.Translation: Terns lay eggs on the face of a glacier.

Grammar.Text: The preverb %iyóo=%i (not %iyoo=%i) may be used instead of %iyéi=%i, where %iyóo=%i is more clearly a quotative and not simply manner; %iyóo%i can be used alone as a quotative marker after a quote. There are two irregular forms of this verb. First, in the imperfective the inalienable incorporated noun %ix̱ʼa-%i ‘mouth’ is always present. Second, when the subject is indefinite human – either the true indefinite or the pseudopassive – then the areal %iḵu-%i prefix is used rather than the expected indefinite human subject %idu-%i. This latter irregularity is cognate with other Na-Dene languages, cf. Tlingit perfective %iyéi ḵuyaawaḵaa%i ‘people said so’ with areal %iḵu-%i and Koyukon %igh%i-perfective %ihʉdegheeneeʼ%i ‘people said’ with areal %ihʉ-%i. Note that this verb is intransitive so the subject phrase is never ergative-marked.

Example.Comment: Alternatively ‘What is he saying?’

Example.Example: De yaa ḵux̱wlig̱át, wáa sá yax̱waaḵaa.
Example.Translation: I already forgot what I said.

Example.Example: Aadóo sá yéi yaawaḵaa, Jéesás dikéenáx̱ yoo kawdudzitéeyi aax̱ sateeyí, gáande has akakg̱wanáa.
Example.Translation: Whoever confesses, that Jesus is a messiah, will be thrown out.

Example.Example: Wáa sá l choosh yáa yoo yeedaḵéik?
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘why don’t you speak to your own face?’, %i–yáa%i = %i–ÿá-ʼ%i ‘face-%sloc%s’.

Example.Example: X̱ʼagáaxʼ áwé litséen yéi yaawaḵaa ax̱ léelkʼw.
Example.Translation: My grandparent said that prayer is powerful.

Example.Example: «Tliyéixʼ, jinaháa haa kát g̱waaxeex» yóo x̱ʼayaḵá du tláa.
Example.Translation: Her mother says “Be still, bad luck might fall on us”.

Grammar.Text: Originally meaning ‘about O, around O’, this has shifted to mean ‘about something to O’. Leer notes that this implies “that one is speaking to him about his situation, not about anyone else”, but this should be verified.

Example.Translation: What’s he talking about to you?
He’s telling me I should buy a stove.

Example.Example: Yéi daayaduḵá, «Tlél kaadéixʼ haa káx̱ sheeteeḵ!».
Example.Translation: He is told “Don’t bring shame upon us!”.

Grammar.Text: The use of %itʼaa-%i ‘landward side of a landmass’ is apparently a metaphor that invokes the image of someone shouting from out on the water or from the shoreline inland toward a town full of people.

Example.Translation: They announced “The salmon are swimming in the creek!”.

Example.Comment: Or perhaps ‘he announced it to them’?

Definition.Definition: S state plainly, without mincing words
S scold, rebuke, jump on N

Example.Example: Ḵúnáx̱ a kaadé yaawaḵaa, yú du sée; kei ḵulahéich yú sgóonxʼ.
Example.Translation: She really scolded her, her daughter; she’s always fighting in the school.

Grammar.Text: The oblique adjunct %ia yáa(xʼ)%i does not seem to vary. The possessive pronoun %ia%i ‘its’ apparently denotes the question or situation being responded to, but it is not syntactically referential and so cannot be replaced by other noun phrases. The appearance of locative %i-xʼ%i is pleonastic since there is already a locative %i-ʼ%i implied by the vowel length of %i–ÿá%i ‘face, vertical surface’.

VerbTheme.Notes: Verify %iḵwáaḵt=%i (∅; —) non-motion derivation as different from %iḵwáaḵx̱=daaḵ=%i (∅; —). Is latter motion instead?

Definition.Definition: S speak wrongly, say something wrong

Grammar.Text: As with the parent verb theme, this can have the quotative preverb %iyóo=%i (not %iyoo=%i) instead of the specified manner preverb %iyéi=%i ‘thus’. This is a transitive verb so the subject noun phrase must have ergative %i-ch%i.

Example.Translation: She told her boy(friend) “I love you”.

Example.Example: At géide ayawsiḵaa du kéekʼ tátgé.
Example.Translation: She spoke against her younger sister yesterday.
Example.Comment: Edwards’s “wrongly” is not presupposed, though it may come from the familial relationship.

Example.Example: Heexw yóo iyawdudziḵáa, ách áwé ḵoowajáḵ.
Example.Translation: A person said you practiced witchcraft, that’s why he killed them.
Example.Comment: The %idu-%i and %iḵu-%i are obviously referential, so this is an obviative construction and not indefinite.

Example.Example: Aadé yawdudziḵaayí yéich áwé, sh tóon wuditee.
Example.Translation: He was offended, because of the way that people had talked to him.

Definition.Definition: S tell O to do V

Grammar.Text: The V is a subordinate-marked verb, comprising the head of a subordinate clause. This is an ordinary subordinate clause, permitting any of the imperfective, perfective, future, or hortative modes. The %i-t%i suffix is the pertingent postposition, here serving its ‘purposive’ function as N&S described it.

Definition.Definition: S ask yay much (of N) for O

Example.Translation: They will charge him for it.

Example.Example: Wáa sá i tláach yasaḵá wé atx̱ʼéeshi?
Example.Translation: How much is your mother charging for that dryfish?

Example.Example: Du jéet aawatée, du een yawusḵáayi aa át.
Example.Translation: He gave him it, the thing that he had promised him.
I will truly promise it to you.

Definition.Definition: S criticize, bawl out, run down O

Example.Translation: He criticized him behind his back.

VerbTheme.DerivGloss: to the opposition of one’s mind

Example.Translation: Have we offended you (by our speech)?

Example.Example: A yáaxʼ yéi ayawsiḵaa «Aadóo x̱ánt sá g̱atuwa.aat?».
Example.Translation: He answered him, “Who should we go to?”.
Never promise to give it to him.

Definition.Definition: S say something to/about O that better applies to S
S say that O is an N
S confess about O to N

Example.Translation: He confessed his sins to her.
I might say something wrong to you.

Example.Example: Haa sʼaatích chʼa du yéet akaawaḵaa.

Definition.Definition: S ask, tell O to say, sing something

Example.Translation: He’s going to ask him to say/sing something.
Don’t ask him to speak, he’s weak in speech.

Definition.Definition: S ask, tell, order O to do something

Example.Example: Yú xʼáatʼ kaadé áa ḵaa jiḵaawaḵaa, yá ḵaa naaxʼú.
Example.Translation: He told them to take them to that island, those corpses.

Example.Example: Aan adulʼeix̱ ax̱áa kaḵachʼáakʼwt áyá áa x̱at jikawduwaḵaa.
Example.Translation: I have been commissioned to carve a paddle with which to dance.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*qaˀw%i ‘man’ < PND %i*qaˀŋ⁽ʷ⁾%i > Eyak %iqaˀ%i ‘husband’, PA %i*–qαŋʼʸ%i ‘husband’ > Aht %i–qanʼ%i, Den %i–qənʼ%i, Koy %i–qunʼ%i, Gwi %i–ką̀įʔ%i, Car %i–ki%i Nav %i–ką̀ʔ%i, Gal %i–kanʼ%i, Hup %i–xaŋʼ%i

Example.Example: Nasʼk.adoogú xʼóow áwé du káa kakg̱wagéi kʼoodásʼ sákw, wé ḵáa tlein.
Example.Translation: It will take three blankets for the shirt, (for) that big man.

Lemma.Comment: Derived from %iḵáa%i ‘man’.

Definition.Definition: O become a man, gain manhood

Grammar.Text: Locally and in Kake the name %iḴaachx̱an.áakʼw%i is used, elsewhere %iḴaachx̱ana.áakʼw%i with an epenthetic vowel %ia%i is more typical.

Encyclopedia.Text: The primary settlement of the %iShtaxʼhéen Ḵwáan%i, the Stikine people. Named after a man called %iḴaachx̱án%i (from %iḵaa ji-x̱án%i ‘one’s hand-near’) who dwelt in Wrangell Harbour before it became a major settlement. Called %iáakʼw%i ‘little lake’ because in olden days there was a bar across the mouth of the harbour which went dry at low tide, thus making the harbour appear to be a small lake. The %iShtaxʼhéen Ḵwáan%i moved to Wrangell Harbour from Old Town (%iKaatslit.aan%i or %iChʼaalʼhit.aan%i, which has slightly better weather) around the time that the Russians began exploring the Stikine River (%iShtaxʼhéen%i). Before that it was a summer fish camp so that smokehouses ringed the harbour, but only loners like %iḴaachx̱án%i stayed there year-round. The harbour is bounded by a small peninsula called %iShaashta.aak Xʼaa%i or ‘Shustak Point’ in English. The small island in the harbour has hosted a %iNaanyaa.aayí%i clan house for many generations. This island is called %iShéiksh Xʼáatʼi%i ‘Shakes’s Island’ after the lineage of %iNaanyaa.aayí%i clan leaders named %iShéiksh%i; any previously existing name has been lost. Wrangell is home to the %iNaanyaa.aayí%i, %iSʼiknax̱.ádi%i, %iKayaashkiditaan%i, %iX̱ookʼeidí%i, and %iX̱eel Ḵwáan%i clans on the Wolf/Eagle side as well as the %iKiks.ádi%i, %iTeeyhittaan%i, %iTaalḵweidí%i, %iḴaach.ádi%i, and %iKaasx̱ʼagweidí%i clans on the Raven side. Members of other clans have developed extended families in Wrangell during the late 19th and 20th centuries, but no new clan houses have been built. The Wrangell Tlingit people underwent extensive aggressive assimilation through the 19th and 20th centuries, but have heavily reinvested in their traditional culture in the last few decades. Wrangell is one of the few traditional communities that were left out of the 1971 Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, but a federally recognized tribal government exists in the Wrangell Cooperative Association.

Example.Translation: The boat set out for Wrangell.

Lemma.Etymology: prob. < Alutiiq, with second syllable by comparison with %iyaakw%i ‘canoe’

Definition.Definition: Kayak, covered one or two person boat traditionally used by the Sugpiaq/Alutiiq, Aleut, etc

Encyclopedia.Text: Only known from Yakutat in the 18th and 19th centuries. Used in the compound %idóogu ḵaayaakw%i ‘skin kayak’. One-person versions were called %itléixʼ kawool%i ‘one-holed’, two-person baidarkas were called %ideiyaaguwuleit%i which De Laguna proposes as possibly from %idéix̱ yaagú wooleit%i. Kayaks were covered with seal skin. One-person craft were paddled with a double-bladed paddle in the typical Eskimo fashion. Two-person craft were recorded by Suría as used with single-bladed paddles, two or three strokes on each side in the Chugachmiut manner and as in a two-person sea otter hunting canoe. “The last kayak was made at Yakutat by the %iTeiḵweidí%i head of Drum House on Khantaak Island, George Ki-ye-quat-kene (%iX̱ʼeiyeig̱aatḵeen%i, 1855–1900), which earned him the nickname ‘Skin Canoe George’. . . It was sewed with porpoise sinew. He used two-bladed paddles with it.”

Lemma.Comment: Nominalization of imperfective %iḵee.á%i ‘it dawns’.

Encyclopedia.Text: Emmons lists this as November in %iYaakwdáat Ḵwáan%i (Emmons 1991: 463), %iJilḵáat Ḵw.%i (id.: 462), %iSheetʼká Ḵw.%i (id.: 425) %iXutsnoowú Ḵw.%i (id.: 461), %iShtaxʼhéen Ḵw.%i (id.: 461). Swanton gives it for November in %iSheetʼká Ḵw.%i (Swanton 1908: 426) but has %iAt Ḵoowú Dísi%i ‘thing’s lair month’ for November in %iShtaxʼhéen Ḵw.%i instead, with %iḴukahaa Dís%i for August. Swanton explains it as “month when people have to shovel snow away from their doors”, though the verb from which the name is derived refers to digging or shoveling in general. De Laguna confirms it for November in %iYaakwdáat Ḵw.%i but also has it for October (De Laguna 1972: 801). Two of De Laguna’s consultants report “that’s the month the bears begin to clean out their house or cave, digging out” (Olaf Abraham) and “that’s the time the bear digs up the den to go in; when all the bears [are] digging their holes to go in” (Maggie Harry).

Lemma.Comment: This is especially variable across dialects because it is frequent and derived from a long verbal phrase.

Definition.Comment: as used for various Tlingit regional groupings

Encyclopedia.Text: Found in a few clan names, apparently used for groups who were previously not Tlingit but who were absorbed into Tlingit society as whole clans.

Definition.Comment: as used for non-Tlingit nations and ethnic groups

Grammar.Text: Not necessary with nations whose names end with %inaa%i, e.g. %iDeikeenaa%i ‘Haida’, but may still be used. Not always used if the referent is obvious, so e.g. %iGinjuchwaan%i ‘Canadian’ may be used to refer to Canadian people without %iḵwáan%i, but use of %iḵwáan%i is more normal.

Definition.Comment: as used for animal groups, e.g. %ix̱áat ḵwáani%i ‘salmon people’, %ikéet ḵwáani%i ‘killerwhale people’, %ig̱ooch ḵwáani%i ‘wolf people’

Grammar.Text: Always marked for possession with %i-ÿí%i, so e.g. %i*x̱áat ḵwáan%i is ungrammatical.

Example.Example: X̱áatg̱aa naa.ádi, naa.átch yú xóots ḵwáani.
Example.Translation: They’re going for fish, those brown bears are always going.

Lemma.Etymology: < CJ %iqʼəláχən%i ‘fence’ < Coast Salishan lgs.; e.g. Twana %iqʼəláχad%i, Lilʼwat %iqʼláχan%i, Nuxalk %iqʼlaχ%i ‘fence’, Musqueam %iqʼə́ləχn%i ‘stockade’
Lemma.Comment: LHR01 erroneously has %ikʼanáax̱án%i with initial velar rather than uvular.

Example.Example: Yanshukáxʼ áwé kʼidéin wutuliyéx̱ yá ḵʼanáax̱án.
Example.Translation: We built the fence really well out here in the wilderness.

Example.Example: Kʼidéin layéx̱ yá ḵʼanáax̱án wé gishoo daaká yís!
Example.Translation: Build this fence well around those pigs!

Definition.Definition: Blessing, as conferred on a person

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*łiʰngit%i < %i*łinaʰ-git%i or %i*łinaː-git%i ‘man-??’, source and meaning of %i-git%i is unclear but may be related to Tsimshianic %igit%i ~ %iget%i ‘man, person, human’; cf. Eyak %iłilaː%i ‘man’ < %i*łinaː%i (%i*n%i > %il%i < %i*l%i); cf. PA %i*də-neː%i ‘man, person, human’; prob. all < PND %i*(łi-)naː%i or the like; folk etymologies often refer to the unrelated %iléin%i ‘tidal flat’
Lemma.Comment: Northern form %ileengít%i with long vowel is archaic, cf. fading vowel in Tongass. Southern form has initial low tone rather than typical pre-stem high tone. All are results of the loss of %i*aʰ%i or %i*aː%i.

Grammar.Text: Not often used for an indefinite or nonreferential person, e.g. ‘some person’, ‘people (generally)’, since the indefinite human pronouns and verb prefixes are available. Definite uses, e.g. ‘that person’, ‘a (particular) person’, ‘one person’, ‘these people’ are instead the norm. Not a proper name.

Example.Example: Lingít áyú yéi yanaḵéich «Yee eedé x̱ʼakḵwatáan».
Example.Translation: A person often says “I am going to speak to you”.

Definition.Comment: used to distinguish traditional objects from modern counterparts; does not necessarily mean ‘Tlingit’, but rather ‘Indian’ or ‘native’

Grammar.Text: Usually occurs as the possessor in a possessive compound but may be in an ordinary syntactic compound, e.g. %ilingít shákw%i ‘wild strawberry’. As such, it seems to be becoming a prenominal adjective. Not usually capitalized as a proper name.

Example.Example: A yáanáx̱ linúkts áwé, lingít shákw.

Grammar.Text: Refers to indigenous North American people rather than to all humans in general, otherwise identical with the first sense above. May be capitalized as a proper name.

Example.Example: Shayadihéin wé Lingít; áyá G̱unanaa yoo tsú aa dax̱duwasáakw, de chʼás á áwé.
Example.Translation: There are many Natives; some among them are called Athabaskans, they’re the only ones [that we Inland Tlingit see].

Definition.Definition: Tlingit, either a person or something belonging to Tlingit culture and tradition

Grammar.Text: Differentiated from ordinary %ilingít%i in writing by capitalization as a proper name. The spoken form is indistinguishable from the generic ‘person’ sense.

Example.Example: Ḵa x̱át tsú, ax̱ toowú yakʼéi yá a káa yéi x̱at gug̱wateeyí yá Lingítx̱ x̱at sateeyí.
Example.Translation: And me too, I’m glad that I will be part of it, this being that I’m Tlingit.
He knows how to write in Tlingit.
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘by Tlingit mouth’, meaning ‘in the Tlingit language’.

Example.Example: Áwé yéi x̱at duwasáakw, Lingít x̱ʼéináx̱, Shaadaaxʼ.
Example.Translation: So that’s how people call me, in Tlingit, %iShaadaaxʼ%i.

Example.Example: Yéi áyá kudayéin, haa ḵusteeyí, Lingítx̱ haa sateeyí uháan.
Example.Translation: This is the way it is, our culture, we who are Tlingit.

Example.Example: Aaá, tláx̱ áyá, Lingítch sh tóox̱ isnóogun.
Example.Translation: Yes, very much, it used to be awkward for a Tlingit (to touch another’s %iat.óowu%i).

Example.Example: Ldakát át yáx̱ áwé, Lingítch wusikóo, wudashée a éex̱ wudux̱oox̱ú.
Example.Translation: Like everything, a Tlingit knows it (an animal), when he asks it for help.

Definition.Definition: Tlingit land, Tlingit country, the land traditionally inhabited and possessed by Tlingit people

Grammar.Text: Always capitalized %iLingít%i though %iaaní%i may not be.
Normally only %iLingít%i is capitalized because %iaaní%i is an ordinary noun rather than a proper name.

Example.Example: Sheetʼká yoo wduwasayi yé, yá Lingít aaní áwé, Sheetʼká.
Example.Translation: The place that people call Sitka, this Tlingit town there, Sitka.

Subentry.Comment: The Inland form is found elsewhere in casual speech, as is %ilintʼaaní%i /%pɬinˈtʼaː.níˑ%p/

Grammar.Text: Involves the generic ‘person, human’ sense of %ilingít%i. Often occurs with %ildakát%i ‘all’ so %ildakát lingitʼaaní%i ‘all the world, the whole world’ (and not ‘every world’). May be either reduced to one word or left as a two word possessive compound. When reduced it exhibits irregular reduction of transsyllabic /t.ʔ/ to tautosyllabic /tʼ/. Often but not necessarily capitalized as a proper name.

Example.Example: Ldakát lingitʼaaní ḵoonóogu kináaxʼ yéi wootee, yú ḵoonóok yú Sheetʼkáxʼ yú Lʼuknax̱.ádi aanḵáawu haat ḵu.éexʼ aan yátxʼi.
Example.Translation: It surpassed all the world’s events, that event in that Sitka the %iLʼuknax̱.ádi%i invited nobles here.

Example.Example: Áyá ḵaa ḵusteeyí áyá, Lingít, yá Lingitʼaaní.
Example.Translation: This is one’s way of life, Tlingit, in this World.
It would think of going out into the world.

Example.Example: Yá lingitʼaaní g̱eixʼ woosh jin toolshát yeisú.
Example.Translation: In the folds of this world we’re still holding each other’s hands.

Definition.Definition: Nasal bridge, bridge of the human nose

Encyclopedia.Text: Essentially as in English. The upper anterior aspect of the human nose extending roughly from the frontal process of the maxillary bone across the two nasal bones to the contralateral frontal maxillary process. Excludes the cartilage of the septum. Not usually applied to other animals, but as with the English term it can easily be extended to many primates due to their fairly similar nasal morphology.

Example.Translation: We are going to drink Hudson Bay tea.

Grammar.Text: A detransitivized form of the previous verb theme.

Definition.Definition: S cause N to take a sip of O
N be caused to take a sip of O

Grammar.Text: Pseudopassivized form of preceding theme.

Lemma.Etymology: < Eng. %iPortland%i; source of %iɬu-%i ‘nose’ unknown and Eng. %ip%i > Tl. %iχʼʷ%i and Eng. %it.l%i > Tl. %itɬʼ%i are unexplained

Encyclopedia.Text: De Laguna (1972: 217) cites this Tlingit placename for Portland, Oregon from George Johnson as told to J.P. Harrington. This is a hapax legomenon, attested nowhere else, but there is no reason to consider it as unusual. Harrington’s transcription of Tlingit was very good, so the spoken form must have been fairly similar to what he recorded. The name must be a borrowing from English because it is meaningless in Tlingit and shows phonological similarity to the English name. The initial %ilu-%i naïvely seems to be Tlingit %i–lú%i ‘nose’ but its purpose and meaning here are obscure. The appearance of %ix̱ʼw%i for English %ip%i is unusual, where we would expect %ikw%i or even %ixʼw%i; it is possible that De Laguna 1972 has a printing error with %ix̣̓%i instead of %ix̓%i. The conversion of English %it.l%i crossing a syllable boundary into Tlingit %itl%i would be unremarkable, but the ejective %itlʼ%i is difficult to explain. The form in Harrington’s notes should be revisited because it is possible that De Laguna 1972 has a mistranscription.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*–łʼaʰ%i < PND %i*(S)-tsʼaw%i ‘breast, breast milk’; cf. Eyak %i–tsʼuː%i ‘breast, teat, nipple’, Eyak %ikʼu-tsʼuː%i ‘breast, teat‘, PA %i*tsʼu%i ‘breast milk’, PA %i*–tsʼuˀ%i ~ %i*–tsʼuweˀ%i ‘breast, breast milk’

Definition.Definition: Breast, of any female mammal but especially human

Grammar.Text: Dialect variant of %ilʼél%i but its distribution is undocumented. Leer lists the high tone form %ilʼál%i from Krause as well as the toneless %ilʼal%i in Tongass Tlingit.

Definition.Comment: used as wealth, as distributed at potlatches

Encyclopedia.Text: Blankets used as wealth are not physically distinct from ordinary blankets called %ixʼóow%i, they are only distinguished by their use. The typical blanket distributed today at potlatches is a red or blue wool safety blanket, often obtained in bulk from marine chandlery firms in Seattle or Vancouver. Other blankets may also be distributed, including ordinary home blankets; such blankets may be personal property of the deceased. Hudson Bay blankets (%iGinjuchwaan/Hinginán xʼóowu%i) and Pendleton blankets (%iWáashdán xʼóowu%i) may also be distributed, but this is rare given their high cost, hence they are a great honour. Commercial duvets and comforters (%ikax̱ʼwáalʼ xʼóow%i) and other heavy bedcovers are not used, though artificial fleece blankets, crocheted blankets and throws, and other similar blankets may be used. Even ferry and airplane blankets occasionally appear as gifts, presumably after having been surreptitiously liberated from their original transportation firms, and such gifts may be looked upon with some suspicion. Chilkat blankets (%inaaxein%i) and other indigenous weaving articles are %iat.óow%i and hence not given away, though they may be commissioned as gifts and thus can be confused for the regular %ilʼée%i. Blankets may or may not be “danced” before being given to the guests. “Dancing” a blanket involves its use as a screen behind which one of the hosts performs a spirit dance (%iyéik utee%i). A corner of the blanket is then used to wipe the sweat off of the dancer’s brow, after which it is folded back up and given away. If not “danced” then blankets are simply given away like other objects and food, but they are more highly esteemed than most other commercially sourced gifts. Blankets do not have a defined trade value today, but the historical record points to their having conventional values in the past. Stocks of blankets are much smaller than in the past, but people are still known to hoard them. When a person is moribund their family members may talk of needing to start buying blankets, thus alluding to the potlatch ceremonies following death. Such talk is viewed as unlucky or even evil behaviour by some people, however.

Grammar.Text: This sense apparently derives from euphemism.

Definition.Definition: Shore pine, swamp pine, muskeg pine, jack pine, black pine, coast pine, bull pine

Encyclopedia.Text: Evergreen coniferous bush or small tree up to 3 m (10 ft). Usually found in muskegs and swamps. Scruffy and irregular habit, often “bonsai-like” due to salt spray, windblown ice, or poor soil, all of which produce high levels of coumarin that distort growth. When sheltered it will grow into a fairly tall and erect tree with a typical pine appearance, though it seems to be outcompeted by other conifers and hence is mostly found only in difficult environments. Needles are dark green and glossy, 4–8 cm (1½–3¼ in) long, and sharply pointed, typically with a slight curve. Needles are usually found in pairs or less commonly in triplets on a short fascicle attached to the branch. Cones are orange-brown and distinctively pine-like rather than spruce-like, 3–6.5 cm (1¼–2½ in) long, often curved backward asymmetrically, sometimes with prickles on each scale. A variant (%iP. c.%i var. %iyukonensis%i) that regularly bears needle triplets was recently documented around Whitehorse. Very closely related to the lodgepole pine (%iP. contorta%i var. %ilatifolia%i Engelm. ex S.Watson 1871) found in the Rocky Mountains region. No Tlingit name for the lodgepole pine is known, but it would be strange to extend the term %ilʼél%i to the lodgepole pine despite being the same species because their appearances are so different. Unlike the widespread use of the lodgepole pine among indigenous people in its region, there is only limited use of the shore pine in its home range. The tree is often confused with the black spruce %idaḵla.á%i because of their similar appearances and environments, and consequently the Tlingit noun %ilʼél%i is often extended cover both, but black spruce is not normally found on the coast. Shore pine wood is usually similar to that of black spruce because of the same environmentally constrained slow growth. Uses are also similar. Known by a variety of English names, and also confused with black spruce by many English speakers.

Grammar.Text: Only occurs with certain nouns and pronouns: %iá%i ‘it’, %ix̱át%i ‘me’ (%ix̱áan%i), %iee%i ‘%sbase%s’ (%iéen%i or %ieen%i), %i–tú%i ‘inside’ (%itóon%i), %iú%i ‘him’ (%ióon%i). The result is a long vowel with high tone (falling in Southern Tlingit) followed by %in%i. Other nouns use the %ieen%i postposition instead, notably including %i–ká%i ‘horizontal surface’, %i–ÿá%i ‘vertical surface’, and %i–jee%i ‘possession’.

Lemma.Etymology: cf. Eyak %i√la%i ‘drink’, PA %i*√naˑŋʸ⁽ʼ⁾%i ‘drink’ e.g. Nav. %i–lą́ą́ˀ%i, Koy. %i–nuːn%i
Lemma.Comment: Has [+D] in the classifier in most verb themes, an irregularity shared with most other Na-Dene languages.

Grammar.Text: When used in the imperfective, this can imply that the subject can drink alcohol. This may have arisen by comparison with English, e.g. “Does he drink?”, or it may have come from using %iat-%i ‘something, indef. nonhum. obj.’ as a euphemism.

Definition.Definition: S drink O completely, drink up O, drink all of O

Encyclopedia.Text: Said when casually giving a physical object to someone by hand. Used whether or not the recipient is expecting to receive the object. Its use is not obligatory; if the recipient is paying attention the speaker may or may not say %iná%i. Not usually used in formal situations, where it could be perceived as rude. Can be used for tossed or thrown objects, e.g. a stick or baseball. Not used offensively, unlike English ‘take this!’.

Definition.Definition: Upriver, in the direction opposite the river’s flow

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*naʰheˀn%i < CJ %i(s)lahál%i ‘stick game’; vowel change %ia%i > %ie%i unexplained; laryngeals %iaʰ%i and %ieˀ%i may be due to Tongass conversion of length and tone of other dialects

Definition.Definition: Lahal, the stick game of the Pacific Northwest

Encyclopedia.Text: E.g. Opodeldoc, Sloan’s Liniment, Bag Balm, Vicks VapoRub, etc. As the foreign name (%igawdáan%i) implies, this is a recent introduction. Horses are largely irrelevant in Tlingit culture today, so that this term is now used mostly for strongly smelling liniments, salves, and ointments applied to human skin to soothe joint and muscle pain. Some homemade traditions exist, which usually include devilsclub (%isʼáxtʼ%i) and other indigenous medical ingredients.

Definition.Definition: Spiritual medicine, medicine to alleviate spiritual or emotional pain

Grammar.Text: The form %ituwunáakw%i is unusual since it includes the possessive suffix on %itú-ÿí%i ‘spirit-possessive’; vowel reduction from free %itoowú%i verifies that this is a morphological compound, however.

Encyclopedia.Text: This term can be applied to physical objects and substances, but is more poetically used to refer to oratory and kind words that soothe a person’s or group’s emotional and spiritual pain. As such, Nora Dauenhauer used it to describe the healing properties of potlatch oratory, where the opposite (guest) clan speaks in ways that help relieve the host clan’s suffering after the death of the individual for whom the potlatch is held.

Definition.Definition: Punk, rotten wood that is crumbly and friable

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*naːqʷ%i; possibly a borrowing from some coastal language to the south

Encyclopedia.Text: The giant North Pacific octopus is one of the largest octopus species, with adults usually around 15 kg (33 lbs) with a 4.3 m (14 ft) arm span, but full grown adults can be up to 45 kg (100 lbs) and larger; one caught in British Columbia was 69 kg (153 lbs) and 7 m (23 ft) across. Life spans are around three to five years; females die brooding over their hundreds of thousands eggs, and males die soon after mating in the spring. The giant North Pacific octopus lives anywhere from the intertidal shore down to 600 m (2000 ft), and there seems to be seasonal migration from shallows to depths. They are masters of camouflage and can change the colour and texture of their skin quite suddenly, which they use for both protection and for hunting. They will eat nearly anything, and have been documented killing even gulls and small sharks. Octopuses can be caught using unbaited covered pots because they seek shelter in cavities, and they can also be caught on hooks if the bait is tempting enough; catching octopuses with a net is essentially impossible, though fishermen may occasionally find one feeding off of fish in their net. Octopuses are quite intelligent but they are shy of humans and are only rarely encountered on the beach, so consequently Tlingit tradition has little to say about their behaviour. Octopus meat is a particularly favoured bait for halibut fishing, and although it is not a primary food there are many Tlingit people who cook and eat octopus meat either fried or in soups. De Laguna (1972: 405) however reports that her consultants in Yakutat did not eat octopus. Steamed octopus has also become popular since the introduction of sushi and other Japanese cuisine, and is usually eaten in the Japanese style with soy sauce (%icháanwaan sáasi%i). The octopus, also traditionally known as ‘devilfish’ in English, is a minor and usually malign character in Tlingit mythology. The %iḴéex̱ʼ Ḵwáan%i and %iHeinyaa Ḵwáan%i tell particularly dramatic stories of enormous devilfish that plague a family or village.

Example.Translation: They have a lot of tentacles, those octopuses.

Encyclopedia.Text: Many Tlingit speakers do not linguistically differentiate squid (%idag̱asaa%i) from octopus (%ináaḵw%i) although they recognize them as physically different animals. The large variety of local squid species are generally lumped together as a single group, with occasional differentiation based on size and colour. Like octopus they are used for bait (De Laguna 1972: 389; Beresford 1789: 174 in De Laguna 1972: 391). Squid was not generally fished for consumption although people did and do still eat them occasionally. De Laguna (1972: 405) describes cleaning of squid by “reaching inside the mouth and pulling out the entrails with a jerk”. A growing commercial fishery for market squid (%iLoligo opalescens%i) exists in Southeast Alaska, mostly sold to Asian markets, but this is a recent development and commercial squid fishing is not a ‘traditional’ occupation. Myths about giant squid are, as De Laguna (1972: 55) notes, probably in reference to the giant North Pacific octopus rather than about squid species. But Swanton’s (1909: 130–132) record of one myth about ‘devilfish’ includes the term %idag̱asaa%i (%idᴀg̣asā′%i) implying that the narrator was referring to squid and not octopus.
Since octopus and squid are frequently used for bait, esp. for halibut fishing, the term has been extended to cover fishing bait in general.

Can occasionally be extended to other Scandinavian groups, e.g. Danish and Swedish, but generally people are aware of the distinctions and will use English terms for the other nationalities. Norwegians immigrated into %iLingít Aaní%i in the early 20th century, forming the majority in Petersburg and sizeable populations elsewhere in e.g. Wrangell, Ketchikan, Craig, and Juneau. Norwegians found the climate and environment of Southeast Alaska to be similar to much of Norway, and most were employed in the familiar fishing or logging industries. Many Tlingit women married Norwegian immigrants, so that there is now a sizeable subgroup of Tlingit–Norwegian people.

Definition.Comment: by boat or vehicle, to known destination

Example.Example: Násʼk yagiyee a kaanáx̱ has yaawa.át.
Example.Translation: They walked across it for three days.

Example.Example: Násʼk a doogú xʼóow áwé du káa kakg̱wagéi kʼoodásʼ sákw, wé ḵáa tlein.
Example.Translation: It will take three leather blankets to cover him for that shirt, that big man.

Grammar.Text: Found in Southern and Tongass Tlingit only, in which dialect it did not undergo syllabic metathesis. For the Northern form see %iwanadóo%i.

Example.Example: Tlél aadé a yeet g̱ayeey.aadi yé, noow yáx̱ awliyéx̱ du hídi.
Example.Translation: There’s no way you can enter it, he built his house like a fort.

Encyclopedia.Text: The connection between this sense and the ‘fort’ sense is not clear, and the two may have separate origins. Alternatively, this may be derived from the ease of fortifying small islands surrounded by cliffs but with flat tops.
Constructed as a palisade of sticks driven into mud, across which a fence is woven. Apparently called so by metaphoric relation to a fort, or perhaps the metaphor runs in the other direction.

Lemma.Comment: Hapax legomenon, known only from a recording of Henry Denny (DD-09, rec’d. 10 Dec. 1970).

Definition.Definition: Nisg̱aʼa, the people of the Nass River valley

Grammar.Text: Initial high tone is predictable in Southern Tlingit; the corresponding Northern form would be %iNusg̱aa%i with low tone.

The initial %ir%i /%pɹ%p/ is an English phoneme and not a Tlingit one; Tlingit speakers may sometimes use %iw%i or even %iÿ%i instead, but %in%i does not occur. A true loanword and not codeswitching despite the unusual phoneme.

Encyclopedia.Text: Occasionally used by ‘old timers’ in reference to Wrangell, both the town and the people. Now mostly considered humorous, but used seriously in some recordings. Refers to the entire town, not to Wrangell Harbour unlike the Tlingit name %iḴaachx̱an.áakʼw%i.

Grammar.Text: A Tlingitized form of Eng. %iWrangell people%i.

Encyclopedia.Text: Used humorously as an equivalent to %iShtaxʼhéen Ḵwáan%i ‘Stikine People’. Occurs in a bilingual pun %iyú Ráangín péepín%i ‘those Wrangell people’ when said to a person from Wrangell, in which the Tlingit determiner %iyú%i ‘that, those’ also functions as the English second person pronoun %iyou%i.

Definition.Definition: S say name of O, call O by name

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘how do people name it?’

Example.Example: Jesus ḵu.aa yá naná áyá « tá » yóo aawasáa.

Definition.Definition: S name O for some characteristic N

Grammar.Text: The %i-ch%i is not ergative, but instead a specialized instrumental. Note that it does not cause %ia-%i → %i0-%i.

Example.Translation: They named him after his work.

Example.Example: Yá a góonnáx̱ wushoowú dei, ách áyá has awlisáa yá aan.
Example.Translation: They named this town after the trail that went across the isthmus.

Lemma.Comment: Often appears as %i-sú%i when following %igoo%i ‘where’, usually written together: %igoosú%i.

Grammar.Text: Very frequently occurs with a suffix, usually a demonstrative (%iyá%i, %ihé%i, %iwé%i, %iyú%i) or a dubitative particle (e.g. %ikwshé%i). May be followed by dubtative %isí%i ~ %isé%i to form %isás%i.

Example.Example: Daa sáwé yéi i toowú asineekw?
Example.Translation: What makes you feel sad so?
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘what makes your mind/feelings ill?’

Example.Example: Wáa sá duwasáakw yáatʼaa Lingít x̱ʼéináx̱?
Example.Translation: What is this called in Tlingit?

Definition.Definition: Generic quantifier, extended from the %iwh%i-question usage

Grammar.Text: When used in a statement rather than a question, %isá%i follows the phrase which represents the quantifier.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘not some how’ or ‘no how’.

Definition.Definition: Name, encompassing personal names, placenames, common nouns (i.e. names for things), and so forth

Definition.Comment: larger semantic range than the English etymon

Encyclopedia.Text: A borrowing from Russian which is fairly rare in Tlingit, but well attested in other Alaskan languages (Eyak %isədingaʼ%i, Ahtna %isidingah%i, Denaʼina %isidinga%i, Alutiiq %isitiinkaaq%i, Yupʼik %isitiinkaq%i). In Russian it standardly means ‘backstrap, back meat’, but in Russian America it came to specifically refer to pork.

Lemma.Etymology: < CJ %isaplél%i ‘flour; bread’ from unk. source lg.

Definition.Definition: Cooked bread, bread that has been baked
Pudding or porridge made from boiled flour

Lemma.Comment: The Naish & Story noun dictionary had an egregious typo %isʼaḵs%i which has been copied elsewhere.

Encyclopedia.Text: The Tlingit bow is traditionally made of yew wood, hence the other sense. It is unclear whether this word originally described the weapon or the tree. The Tlingit bow is a basic flatbow of typical Northwest Coast shape. It is held horizontally with a palm-upward or Mongolian draw. De Laguna (1972) and Emmons & De Laguna (1991) offer illustrations from early European explorers. Although totally superseded by modern firearms, a few enthusiasts continue to construct and practice with traditional bows. Children still play with toy bows made from opportune materials, but the traditional grip and technique have been replaced by generic American Indian imagery. Use of the traditional Tlingit bow as an actual weapon in the modern era is unknown, though some Tlingits use modern compound bows in hunting and competition.

The Pacific yew is native to the southernmost parts of %iLingít Aaní%i. It is a small tree, sometimes shrubby, with relatively long and flat needles having a narrow ridge along the upper surface. The needles are whorled around the branch, but they lie flat and appear to be two-ranked. The hard but flexible yew wood is highly valued in Tlingit culture, traditionally used for bowyery, war clubs, wedges, and other tools requiring toughness, flexibiliy, and strength. Modern carvers make masks and other small pieces from yew wood, and they praise its workability and pleasant smell.

The red ‘berries’ of the yew tree are edible and consumed by birds; they are actually cup-like arils that surround but do not completely enclose the 2–4 angled seeds. In contrast, the seeds are highly poisonous; they pass through the digestive tract of birds but will decompose within the human gut especially if chewed. The general rarity of yew trees in %iLingít Aaní%i and the poisonousness of the seeds has led to Tlingits largely ignoring the %isáḵs tléig̱u%i as a source of food, though indigenous groups further south along the coast do eat them.

Definition.Definition: Large dog, often a guard dog

Lemma.Comment: May also be high tone. Also spelled %istoox%i by similarity with English, but only pronounced %isdoox%i with unaspirated %id%i in the onset cluster. This mirrors the English phonotactics of %isC%i clusters. Occasionally %ishdoox%i with initial %ish%i indicating possible borrowing through Haida or Coast Tsimshian which lack a %is%i – %ish%i distinction.

Definition.Comment: either a cooking surface or a contained fireplace, as in English

Example.Example: X̱ʼaan yeenayátʼch wé yées sdoox tóoxʼ.
Example.Translation: The fire lasts in the new stove.

Example.Example: Sdoox káa yan sa.ín wé attéix̱i.
Example.Translation: Set the broth on top of the stove.

Lemma.Etymology: < Eng. %iSeattle%i /%psiˈjæ.tl̩%p/ < Straits Salish %iSiʔaːɬ%i, a personal name

Definition.Definition: Seattle, the city in Washington state

Grammar.Text: Tone on the second syllable varies among speakers, so e.g. with %i-dé%i it may be %iSeeyaatldé%i or %iSeeyáatlde%i.

Encyclopedia.Text: A straightforward borrowing from English, but interpreting the final syllable as a lateral affricate. Seattle looms large in the life of Tlingit people, being a home for many families and a major travel destination for others. The Tlingit community in the Seattle region is widely dispersed, but there are regular governmental and cultural meetings. Many if not most Tlingit residents of Seattle return home to families and friends in Alaska on a regular basis. Airline travel from Alaska to the rest of the United States typically passes through Seattle, and hence many Tlingit people are more familiar with the Sea-Tac airport than the average Seattle resident. Tlingit residents of Southeast Alaska often travel to Seattle for shopping trips, and Tlingits in commercial fishing commonly travel to Seattle for major marine services. Large goods such as furniture, automobiles, and boats are often bought in Seattle and shipped back by barge or on the Alaska ferry, and some families make yearly pilgrimages there to purchase household necessities in large quantities. The equivalent for Canadian Tlingits is Vancouver BC (%iWankóowaa%i, q.v.).

Definition.Comment: either animal or inanimate with a head-like projection

Definition.Definition: causation, means for existence or occurrence, chain of events
S grab up, snatch, take hold of O

Example.Comment: Lit. “smoke took hold of her body”.

Definition.Definition: S arrest, catch, grab O (fleeing entity)

Example.Translation: They sent guards after him to arrest him.

Example.Example: Tléil kei gax̱dusháat, ḵaa yáanáx̱ yagóot.
Example.Translation: He won’t get caught, he goes faster than anyone.
We caught salmon in a fishtrap.

Definition.Definition: S grab, take O (away) from N

Example.Translation: He didn’t grab it up from there.

Definition.Definition: S drag away O (human) from N

Example.Translation: While she was being watched she was dragged away from there.

VerbTheme.DerivGloss: seaward; out into open; falling from sky; onto fire

Definition.Definition: S grab O and take out into open

Example.Translation: He didn’t grab it and take it out.

Definition.Definition: S grab O for N, quickly take O to N

Example.Comment: More than one.

Definition.Definition: S (wind, weather) hit N in gusts, bursts

Example.Translation: The north wind hit us in gusts.

VerbTheme.Notes: Needs more investigation.

Example.Translation: He can’t make up his mind.

VerbTheme.Notes: Needs more investigation.

Definition.Definition: S give in to N, decide to follow N’s advice

VerbTheme.Notes: Needs more invesigation.

Definition.Definition: S go around warily, suspiciously at N

Example.Example: Wé dóosh du jín dleit kaax̱ kínde alshát.
Example.Translation: That cat is holding its paw up off of the snow.
Example.Comment: Includes %iN-dáx̱%i adjunct and %iN-dé%i adjunct but no motion derivation.

Example.Example: Wé yaakw yax̱akʼáaw kasʼéet áa yéi du.óowu, kʼidéin yéi agux̱lasháat.
Example.Translation: If a screw is put there into the thwart of the boat, it will hold well.
He’s holding (on to) the boat; he was saved.

Example.Example: Líl yóox̱ eeltoox̱óoḵ, chʼa g̱alsháat sʼé.
Example.Translation: Don’t spit it out, just hold it (in your mouth) first.

Definition.Definition: S capture O, hold O captive
S grab O and hold at N

Lemma.Comment: Alternative form of %isdoox%i with initial %ish%i indicating possible borrowing through Haida or Coast Tsimshian, both of which lack a %is%i – %ish%i distinction.

Definition.Definition: Primary limb of a tree, branch growing from the trunk of a tree
Knot in wood, the location in a piece of wood where a limb grew
Tree limb found drifting in salt water
Definition.Comment: lit. ‘limb from bottom of salt water’

Lemma.Comment: A variant %ishéex̱ʼw%i is predictable but only once attested.

Encyclopedia.Text: Largest species of alder in North America, 20–30 m. Bark is grey and smooth, with the inner bark turning a characteristic rusty red colour when exposed to air. The exposed bark colour is similar to robin breast feathers, and the two Tlingit words are related. Leaves are 7–15 cm, serrated and pointed, with the edge curled under. Male catkins 10-15 cm long, brick red. Female catkins turn into 2–3 cm long dry cone-like fruit. The wood is slightly pinkish to yellowish, relatively soft for a hardwood but harder than cottonwood, willow, and conifers. A favourite food of beavers, though less favoured by deer. Found throughout coastal Tlingit country south to central coastal California, usually in creek bottoms, old landslides, and other disturbed sites. A typical stand of mature trees can be seen at Indian River in Sitka. The wood is ideal for smoking; opinions vary on whether the bark should be removed or not but the best harvest time for smoking is unanimously in spring when the sugar content is high. The wood is also used for tool handles, drumsticks, masks, bowls, clan hats, and other small to moderate sized carvings. Large branches and small trunks are also used to make chairs, table legs, and stair balusters. The bark is used as a traditional dye, and is sometimes used to treat irritated insect bites. Fresh leaves put off prodigious smoke which is too bitter for smoking food and too greasy for smoking skins, but the smoke is a good smudge to keep off insects. De Laguna (1972: 32) confuses red alder %ishéix̱ʼw%i and beach alder %ikeishísh%i and fails to differentiate them, but she records Jack Reed saying “cix̓” which is probably %ishéex̱ʼw%i or %ishéix̱ʼw%i (De Laguna 1972: 1158). Alder is used for the lower half of a halibut hook, the upper half being yellow-cedar (De Laguna 1972: 355, 388, 869). The bark was added to dried and ground tobacco to give it a sharper flavour (De Laguna 1972: 411). Red alder is used to make sticks for the %ishísht%i gambling game (De Laguna 1972: 554). Alder branches are used to beat the skin after cold water training (De Laguna 1972: 479), and temporary bath houses are made from an inverted basket of bent alder branches and small trunks covered with blankets or skins (De Laguna 1972: 306). “Alderberries” – the male catkins? – are split and part of one’s food is inserted into them as a magic %ihéix̱waa%i to control appetite (De Laguna 1972: 765, 815). MJ describes %iTéikʼ Éesh%i as using a split alder stick called %ishóoch%i to hold a cut land otter tongue for shamanic use (De Laguna 1972: 679–680). Alder branches were used for a mock cremation of a doll to clear weather (De Laguna 1972: 807). The G̱alyáx̱ Kaagwaantaan Beaver was found in an alder tree (De Laguna 1972: 254).
Derived by metonymy from the bark of the tree.

Lemma.Comment: Widely varying dialectally and idiolectaly, including forms like %ishéi%i, %ishéeyi%i, and %ishée%i, the latter being equal to the name of Baranof Island. Often confused with %isheey%i ‘primary limb, knot’, but note tone.

Encyclopedia.Text: The prototypical tree in Coastal Tlingit culture. Cones are long and short-stalked, with diamond-shaped to elliptic scales that are thin and flexible. Needles are triangular and quite sharp. Possibly hybridizes with white spruce in the interior. Roots are essential for basketry, and were used to the exclusion of redcedar bark among the far Northern Tlingit, e.g. the typical “Tlingit hat”; redcedar bark is easier to work and now easier to obtain, hence increasing in popularity. The wood traditionally replaced redcedar wood in the north for houses and canoes, though redcedar was still much preferred. Spring shoots were eaten, though this is rare today.

Definition.Definition: White spruce, by equation with Sitka spruce

Encyclopedia.Text: Not usually differentiated from Sitka spruce, but see below for an innovative term that is distinct.

Grammar.Text: Because of the %i-yi%i ending this appears to be a possessive compound but it is not.

Encyclopedia.Text: Traditionally Sitka spruce and white spruce were not differentiated. White spruce cones are often somewhat shorter than Sitka spruce and have rounded, fan-shaped scales. The cones are the easiest diagnostic for distinguishing the two species. Needles are similar. Growth is generally smaller than Sitka spruce, but this is probably mostly due to climate. Hybridizes with Sitka spruce where the two species ranges’ overlap, such as along the continental river valleys. The dominant conifer of much of %iDaḵká Lingít Aaní%i, the Inland Tlingit Country. The oldest recorded white spruce is at Kluane Lake, dated at 668 years when sampled. Traditional uses are largely the same, though the gum made from white spruce sap was considered far superior to that from Sitka spruce and thus on the coast was a trade item obtained from the Inland Tlingit and Athabaskans.

Definition.Definition: Douglas-fir or other coniferous tree similar to Sitka spruce

Encyclopedia.Text: Tlingit people outside of traditional Tlingit territory now encounter many spruce and spruce-like trees such as Douglas-fir. Such trees are now also intentionally planted in some towns in %iLingít Aaní%i. This term has been proposed as a suitable vocabulary item for spruce-like trees, though differentation from Sitka spruce may not matter much in practice.

Definition.Definition: Douglas fir or other coniferous tree similar to Sitka spruce

Lemma.Etymology: < Eng. %ischooner%i /%pˈsku.nəɹ%p/, a type of small sailing vessel

Sense.Notes: Leer notes ‘what if’ but this doesn’t fit with the rest of the definitions.

Encyclopedia.Text: The well-known robin of North America, actually a species of thrush, and only distantly related to the European robin. The rusty red breast is used metonymically as a colour referent, so %ishoox̱ʼ yáx̱ yatee%i ‘it is robin-like’ refers to this colour. They migrate south in September or October and reappear the following March or April. De Laguna (1972: 48) seems to describe them as newcomers to Yaktuat, but she actually refers to her own experience rather than robins being new to the community. The robin has a rather minimal presence in Tlingit myth. Swanton (1909: 85) has Robin appearing in Raven’s naming of the birds, where Raven says “You will make the people happy by letting them hear your whistle. You will be a good whistler”, in the Raven cycle by Katishan. De Laguna (1972: 868) cites Jack Ellis in saying that Robin got his belly burned in a fire where Raven was roasting king salmon.
Derived by metonymy from the male robin’s breast feathers.

Similar in size and appearance to the robin, hence the Tlingit name. Slightly shorter and bulkier than a robin, with much brighter and lighter orange colouration as well as a black band across the breast on males. Migratory, with arrival and departure dates similar to the robin.

Example.Translation: Careful, watch yourself, you might get shocked.

Definition.Definition: O talk in an affected or cute way for N

Encyclopedia.Text: Among other things, describes using an excessive amount of the diminutive suffix %i-kʼ%i, especially labialized %i-kʼw%i.

Lemma.Comment: Alternative spelling of %isdoox%i, by similarity with English. The %it%i is not actually aspirated.

Definition.Definition: Bone, either the material or the whole object
Supposedly ‘bow; yew’ but actually a typo for %isáḵs%i found in the Naish & Story noun dictionary and perpetuated in other materials

Grammar.Text: If this were a real word it would be expected to have high tone in Northern Tlingit because of the short vowel and closed monosyllabic structure.

Encyclopedia.Text: The quintessential Tlingit medical plant; the ethnographic literature is laden with descriptions of its myriad uses. A large woody shrub 1–5 m (3–16 ft) tall, thickly covered with sharp ½–1 cm (¼−½ in) spines on branches and leaf veins. Stems are woody with a hollow core filled with white spongy tissue, hence sometimes referred to as its ‘bones’ (%ia sʼaag̱í%i). Bark is light green when new, with a silver-brown papery membrane forming on the outside during maturity. Leaves are large, 20–40 cm (8–16 in) across, palmately lobed, and spirally distributed on the stems. Flowers are small in dense umbels with greenish to white petals. The fruit is a small red berry-like drupe, inedible to humans but feasted upon by birds and animals (esp. bears) in the fall. For medical use the stems are harvested, preferably in the early spring before the leaves have opened. Care is taken to avoid overharvest by leaving a majority of stems per plant since growth is quite slow. Traditionally a heavy piece of leather (%iat xáshti%i) would be used to grasp the plant, though in modern practice leather work gloves (%iyawusʼi tsáaxʼ%i) are used. Once harvested, the spines are scraped off, usually with a dull knife or tin can lid (%ishísʼaa%i). The bark is split and peeled off the cut stems, then the outer silvery membrane is scraped off. The resulting inner bark is usually cut into small pieces and dried, then used for tea. The flavour is soapy, bitter, earthy, and unpleasant, with an easily identified earthy and acrid smell. Alternate preparations include crushing and powdering, delivered in an oil for ingestion (traditionally hooligan oil %isaak eex̱í%i or seal oil %itsaa eex̱í%i) or in a paste for topical use. Modern practice includes steam distillation using home equipment, producing an oil that is mixed into carrier oils or fats, or into commercial petroleum jelly. Overdose by ingestion is possible but rare; reported effects include nausea, vertigo, disorientation, vomiting, tachycardia, and hypertension. Contraindicated for individuals with hypertension or kidney disorders since it is a mild diuretic, and for those with hypoglycemia because it may be a hypoglycemic. May also be contraindicated for individuals with clotting disorders because it interferes with platelet aggregation. Stems are also widely used as amulets, usually with the spines intact. These are hung over doorways to ward off evil, and may also be hung in trees around campsites. Old amulets may be burned or discarded in the forest.
The glacier bear is an uncommon phase of the black bear with a pronounced silver-blue coloration to much of its fur. The term ‘glacier’ is from the colour, not from behaviour or habitat.

Lemma.Comment: Northern Tlingit variant of %i√sʼiḵ%i, with uvular lowering of the vowel.
Northern Tlingit variant of %i√sʼiḵ%i ‘smoke’ with uvular lowering of the vowel.

VerbTheme.Notes: The %idu-%i derivation causes [−D], but what %idu-%i means is unclear. Imperfective unknown so stative vs. active unclear, but likely %i-h%i stem.

Encyclopedia.Text: Primary crest of the Deisheetaan clan, also used by the G̱aanax̱.ádi clan. In art the beaver appears with small ears, long incisors, and a broad crosshatched tail, and is often holding a stick on which it gnaws. The Inland Deisheetaan use a beaver with six legs, copper claws, and a split tail.

Lemma.Comment: The %i√sʼeḵ%i variant is found in Northern Tlingit and arises from uvular lowering of the vowel.

Definition.Definition: S drink O through a straw

Example.Translation: He’s drinking water through a straw.
I had been sucking the orange.
Example.Comment: Repetitive %i-sʼ%i epiaspect in the perfective mode.

Grammar.Text: May also be %i∅%i-conjugation.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘thing through which people suck something’

Lemma.Comment: Southern and Tongass form of %i√sʼeḵ%i ‘smoke’ without uvular lowering.

Encyclopedia.Text: Refers to several kinds of metamorphic rock including greenschist, jadeite, and nephrite. Before the widespread availability of metal tools, greenstone was the ideal material for making adze heads, picks, and other large cutting implements. The name for the rock probably derives from its use for making chopping implements so that the root %i√sʼuʼw%i ‘chop’ is the source of the noun.
From the colour of greenstone, used as a generic referent for green colours.

The colour denotation of %isʼoow%i seems to have shifted from green to blue in Inland Tlingit due to the lack of use of stone tools. The colour green is generally referred to with %ikayaaní%i ‘leaf’ in Inland Tlingit. Since %isʼoow%i no longer seems to have an entity referent, in Inland Tlingit the word can be considered a basic colour term.

Example.Translation: we’re going to chop it in two
Turnip boiled with carrots is good.
We had already boiled the flour.

Example.Example: Sʼáxtʼ káx̱i ḵa sháachʼ áyú dustáayjin náakw sákw.
Example.Translation: Devilsclub and %isháachʼ%i used to be boiled for medicine.
Those grey currants have already been boiled.

Definition.Definition: S boil O (small round food, e.g. berries)
O (animal) be completely fat, be in prime condition for hunting

Example.Translation: Deer are fully fat in the fall.

Example.Example: Yan uwatáa hasdu gishookʼú, ách áwé has aawajáḵ.
Example.Translation: Their little pig had gotten completely fat, so they killed it.

Lemma.Comment: Only in Tongass Tlingit.
Leer gives conflicting notes on the Tongass form, which may be due to fading vowel and sonorant interaction.

Grammar.Text: Only known from Tongass Tlingit, conjugation class unknown, no perfective form recorded.

Encyclopedia.Text: Any sort of dish where food has been boiled, usually as a soup.

Grammar.Text: Used in attributive constructions to indicate the result of boiling a food item.

Definition.Definition: Pudding or porridge made from boiled flour
Something used for boiling, for broth

Definition.Comment: e.g. human body odour, ravens, onions

Example.Example: Tlax̱ a yáanáx̱ wulitéx̱ du húnx̱u, ách áwé ḵaa x̱oodáx̱ gánde kawduwanáa.
Example.Translation: His older brother smelled too much, that’s why he was told to go outside away from among people.

Encyclopedia.Text: Applies to any species within the order Actiniaria, as with the English noun ‘sea anemone’.

Grammar.Text: Usually translated as ‘see’ but is more precisely ‘catch sight of’ or ‘lay eyes on’. Since this theme is an eventive there is no imperfective; the perfective can mean either ‘he sees it’ or ‘he saw it’ depending on context, but the past tense translation is more common.

Example.Example: Dzískw awusteení tle a dachóon kei uwagút.
Example.Translation: When he saw the moose he went straight up to it.

Example.Example: Dleit yáx̱ yateeyi át héen x̱ookaadé wududziteen.
Example.Translation: A white thing on the water was seen.
I saw it on his face.
Don’t be as if you suspected their presence.
He figured what happened to him was on account of what he was doing, the result of his actions.
Example.Notes: This translation needs to be reviewed.

Definition.Definition: S be able to see O

Example.Translation: When it is daylight, everything can always be seen.

Example.Example: Chʼa ax̱ shantóoxʼ x̱aatéen aadé yéi kwḵasanei yé.
Example.Translation: In my mind I can see the way that I will make it.

Example.Example: Yeeytéen hasdu téix̱ʼ tóotx̱ áyá toodé has yee uwaxích haa ḵu.éexʼi.
Example.Translation: You all can see our hosts thank you from within their hearts.

Definition.Definition: S have sight, have vision, have ability to see

Example.Example: Tléil ḵoox̱shatéeneen, yá yeedát ḵu.aa ḵux̱aatéen.
Example.Translation: I used to be blind, but now I can see.

Example.Comment: Henya dialect?
Henya dialect?

Definition.Comment: not used for social ‘recognition’, only for the basic cognitive phenomenon

Example.Comment: Said when one should know the person.

Encyclopedia.Text: Themes derived from this can be used for travel by any kind of transportation other than by foot. The meaning derives from ‘see an area’ with the areal %iḵu-%i ‘area; indefinite place, somewhere’.

Definition.Definition: S take a trip to N

Example.Translation: I’m going to take a trip to Juneau.

Example.Notes: Check translation − looks like habitual so maybe ‘he doesn’t come here?’.

Example.Example: G̱ayéisʼ tʼéix̱ʼi sháade háni haat ḵoowatín tatgé.
Example.Translation: The chief blacksmith came here yesterday.

Example.Example: Yá ḵutaanxʼ aadé ḵugax̱tootéen ixkée chʼa g̱aax̱tusatéen wé sháa.
Example.Translation: This summer we’re going to travel down south just so we can see the girls.

Example.Comment: Subordinate perfective, not conditional or contingent.

Example.Translation: What did she travel down south for?

Example.Example: Haadé yaa s ḵunatín Wáashdán Ḵwáan.

VerbForm.Gloss: he keeps starting to travel there

Definition.Definition: S start to travel toward N
S travel to the other side of N

Example.Example: X̱ʼaan yáx̱ teeyí gisʼóoḵ, tléil dultínx̱.
Example.Translation: When the Northern Lights are red, people don’t watch them.
They’re looking at it from the woods.

Definition.Definition: S mind, take care of, look after O

Example.Translation: Are you taking good care of yourself?

Definition.Definition: S mind, take care of, look after O
S watch, take care of self

Example.Translation: Take care of yourself; be careful.

Definition.Definition: S take a good look at O

Example.Translation: I came here, in order to observe people’s way of life.
I’m going to study her way of life.

Definition.Definition: S finish taking a good look at O

Example.Example: Du yéi jinéiyi de yan kax̱wlitín.

Example.Translation: I can’t make out what it is.
You’re watching it so hard it looks like it’s not there.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘thing on which he travels around it’
lit. ‘through it people can be seen’

Definition.Definition: Copper shield-like item with a characteristic eight-sided kite shape

Encyclopedia.Text: Traditionally used as a kind of very valuable currency, now largely ceremonial. Often decorated with clan symbols by etching, engraving, and staining. Originally manufactured from native copper obtained by trade from the Ahtna, later devalued by trade in European sheet copper. Small examples are used as jewelry today.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tłaʰˈguː%i < PND %i*(S-)tsa⁽⁾g-e⁽⁾%i ‘of old, long ago’; cf. Eyak %itsahg(-ł)%i ‘legend, tale’, Alaskan Ath. %i*qʊ-zaːxʸ%i ‘areal?-story’ > Deg. %ixəðoxʸ%i ‘story’, Koy. %iχʌloxʸ%i ‘story’

Grammar.Text: Appears to have possessive suffix %i-ÿí%i but does not, possessed form is %itlaagóowu%i.

Example.Example: Tlaagú áyú aadé at wooneiyi yé.
Example.Translation: What happened was just like a legend.
