Subentry.Comment: Also %ichaa tlaagú!%i and %icha tlaagú!%i among others.

Definition.Definition: ‘Amazing!’, ‘Unbelievable!’. Expression when one has heard something shocking or suprising
Definition.Comment: lit. ‘just legendary’ or ‘just mythical’, more loosely ‘like in a story!’

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tlaguʰ%i < %i*tłagu-wu%i < %i*tłagu-ÿi%i ‘ancient-time’ < PND %i*(S)tsa⁽⁾g-e⁽⁾%i ‘of old, long ago’ with %i*-e⁽⁾%i ‘time’; cf. PA %i*saːgʸeː%i ~ %i*saːgʸeˀ%i ‘id.’ > Gal. %isai-dąˀ%i ‘story’, Alaskan Ath. %i*=tsaːgʸ(…)%i ~ %i*=sagʸ(…)%i ‘old, worn out’ > Deg. %i=tθog%i, Koy. %i=tłogəyi%i etc., Gwi. %i=šik%i; also Nav. %i=sáːˀ%i ‘old, abandoned; dried up, withered’

Grammar.Text: Not a true adjective, instead actually a noun possessing the following noun.

Encyclopedia.Text: Refers to a time known only from legends, not events known by an explicit chain of oral transmission. This may include times up to and beyond European contact, but largely excludes times since the American purchase of Alaska.

Grammar.Text: Archaic form of the adverb %itlákw%i still found in songs and narratives.
A variant of %itlagoo%i, probably by phonological reduction and stress shift %itlaˈgoo%i → %iˈtlagu%i → %itlágu%i. The form %itlákw%i is possible but collides with the adverb.

VerbTheme.Etymology: < PT %i*O-S-[∅]-tłaʰgʷ%i < %i*O-S-[ł]-tsaʰgʷ%i < PND %i*(S-)tsa⁽⁾gʷ%i; cf. Eyak %iO-tsahg%i ‘tell legend, tale of O’

Grammar.Text: This verb theme is not used for historical stories, procedural texts, or other non-legendary narratives, for which see %i√neek˟%i.

Example.Translation: Long ago they tell it (a legend) thus.

VerbTheme.Etymology: prob. orig. deprecatory ‘tell tales’ < PT %i*qu-S-[∅]-tlaʰgʷ%i < %i*qu-S-[ł]-tsaʰgʷ%i < PND %i*(S-)tsa⁽⁾g%i; cf. PA %i*qʊ-ł-zaːgʸ%i ‘tell legend, tale’ > Koy. %iχʌ-ł-loxʸ/lok%i ‘tell legend, tale’

Grammar.Text: Optional adjunct of either %iN een%i or %iN-dé%i, possibly also %iN–tú-dé%i.

Example.Translation: I’m going to whisper (it) to you.
They found out where it was.

Definition.Definition: S include self (in a story) at N

Example.Translation: He always says he’s been here and there.
Example.Comment: Motion derivation %iN-t%i (%ina%i; —) ‘around N’.

Example.Translation: He included himself there (in the story).
Example.Comment: I.e. saying “I was there too.” Motion derivation %iN-{t,x̱,dé}%i (∅; %i-h%i Rep) ‘arriving at N’.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tlaguʰ%i < %i*tłagu-wu%i < %i*tłagu-ÿi%i ‘ancient-time’ < PND %i*(S)tsa⁽⁾g-e⁽⁾%i ‘of old, long ago’ with %i*-e⁽⁾%i ‘time’; cf. PA %i*saːgʸeː%i ~ %i*saːgʸeˀ%i ‘id.’ > Gal. %isai-dąˀ%i ‘story’, Alaskan Ath. %i*=tsaːgʸ(…)%i ~ %i*=sagʸ(…)%i ‘old, worn out’ > Deg. %i=tθog%i, Koy. %i=tłogəyi%i etc., Gwi. %i=šik%i; also Nav. %i=sáːˀ%i ‘old, abandoned; dried up, withered’
Lemma.Comment: The form %itlágu%i is archaic but found in some songs and narratives.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tłagu-wu ʔaʰn%i < %i*tłagu-ÿi ʔaʰn%i ‘ancient-time village’; cf. Tan. %iθog-a kayəχ%i ‘old village site’ (lit. ‘old-time village’)

Definition.Definition: Klukwan (Eng. pron. /ˈklʌkˌwɒn/ or /ˌklʌkˈwɒn/), a village of the Jilḵáat Ḵwáan, on the Chilkat River upstream from Haines

Encyclopedia.Text: Earlier spelled ‘Cluckwan’, ‘Kluckwan’, etc. The name refers to its status as a very old village site, possibly one predating the arrival of Tlingit people.

Definition.Definition: A village in Aangóon Ḵwáan, now abandoned
Definition.Notes: Need location; appears in list of villages from N&S recording.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tlaykʼ%i < PND %i*də=łV-qʼ%i ‘one, together, all’ (mphg. unclear) per Leer (2000), who also says %itléikʼ%i is a doublet with %itléixʼ%i ‘one’.
Lemma.Comment: Sometimes pronounced as %itlaekʼ%i /tɬʰæːkʼ/ and %itlaykʼ%i /tɬʰæjkʼ/ (note low tone) which are archaic forms but now considered ‘slangy’.

Lemma.Etymology: < %itléikʼ-l%i ‘no-not’ per Leer (2000) but could also be %itlé-l%i ‘just-not’

Example.Translation: It isn’t; it does not exist.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tłʼiʰx%i; PND form unclear, cf. Eyak %itłʼitsʼ%i ‘dirt, dust’, Eyak %itłʼəǯ%i ‘slush’, Eyak %itłʼəčʼg%i ‘snot, gelatin’, PA %i*tłʼəˀč%i ~ %i*tłʼəˀš(gʸ)%i ‘mud, goo, slime’

Definition.Definition: Trash, rubbish, junk, garbage, filth, mess

Subentry.Comment: Initial syllable may also be long.

Grammar.Text: A noun compound of %itú%i ‘mind’ and %iÿá%i ‘face’ with the locative suffix %i-ʼ%i which is an allomorph of %i-xʼ%i ‘at’. Must be possessed.

Definition.Definition: Mind, feelings, inner experiences and emotions, spirit

Grammar.Text: The possessed form of %itú%i ‘mind’, which is somewhat surprisingly an alienable noun.

Definition.Definition: Game fence, barricade for game animals

Encyclopedia.Text: Previously used for any kind of fence, now restricted as the general sense has been replaced by %iḵʼanáax̱án%i. Usually constructed in pairs forming a funnel together, but referred to as a single entity. For small game animals like rabbits the central opening would have a snare, but for large game like deer or caribou there could be either a deadfall or hunters would wait in ambush. More popular among the Inland Tlingit than among the Coastal Tlingit, though the latter knew its construction and used it. Rarely used today, though some hunters still make them for large game.

Definition.Definition: S block off, dam up O

Example.Translation: I dammed the water in order to extend it to the beach.
He blocked it off (posts in a breakwater).
They used to dam it up.

Encyclopedia.Text: Applied indiscriminately to the Northwestern crow (%iC. caurinus%i) and the American crow (%iC. brachyrhynchos%i), which are difficult to tell apart for non-experts and are usually distinguished only by geography. Never applied to the Common raven (%iC. corax%i) except by mistake, which is instead always %iyéil%i (q.v.). Distinguishing crows and ravens can be difficult to the untrained eye, but most Tlingits can tell the difference at least from their calls if not visually. The crow does not have any significant presence in Tlingit myth, being completely overshadowed by Raven. Crows show up very occasionally in histories and legends, but then only as animals and as background characters. The crow population is greater in more southerly regions of %iLingít Aaní%i, and in the Inland Tlingit territory they are mostly absent. Raven told crows to be noisy and talkative, and it is said that on hearing one crow several others will soon be heard (Swanton 1909: 86). The crow is not generally a symbol in Tlingit culture, but De Laguna (1972: 46) notes a Yakutat clan of the Raven moiety as claiming Crow for a crest. A crow’s cry may be a bad luck omen if it sounds like weeping or wailing (De Laguna 1972: 829).

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*tsʼiwtsˈxan%i < %i*tsʼimtsˈxan%i < C.Tsim. %i*tsʼimtsxʸan%i; borrowed from an earlier stage of Coast Tsimshian, cf. C.Tsim. %itsʼmsyan%i

Definition.Definition: Tsimshian people (Eng. pron. /%pˈsɪmˌʃi.æn%p/ or /%pˈsɪmˌʃɪn%p/), in English also known specifically as Coast Tsimshian in contrast to the Nisg̱aʼa (Eng. /%pˈnɪʃˌgʌ%p/ or /%pˈnɪsˌgʌ%p/) and Gitksan (Eng. /%pˌgɪt.kəˈsæn%p/) who are also sometimes called ‘Tsimshian’

Encyclopedia.Text: Today this term includes both people from (New) Metlakatla in Alaska as well as those from British Columbia.

Lemma.Comment: Unpredictable tone and length when suffixed: %i–too-CV(C)%i, %i–tóo-C%i

Definition.Definition: Inside of something relatively deep or enclosed

Encyclopedia.Text: Applies to living things (e.g. human, dog), solid objects (rock, log), completely enclosed hollow objects (basketball, box), tubular objects (pipe, nose), deep cavities (rabbit hole, sinkhole), and deep containers (teapot, bucket). Does not apply to buildings (house, tent), vehicles (canoe, car), bodies of water (river, lake), open landforms (valley, canyon), or shallow containers (bowl, pot).

Definition.Definition: Mind, feelings, inner experiences and emotions, spirit

Grammar.Text: Alienable, though semantically one might expect an inalienable noun. Thus usually possessed, e.g. %iax̱ toowú%i ‘my mind, feelings’.

Encyclopedia.Text: The inside of a person as the locus of mental life, in contrast to the outside world.

Lemma.Etymology: poss. calqued from an Ath. source, given similar structures in e.g. Aht., Den.

Encyclopedia.Text: Known elsewhere in the Pacific Northwest as e.g. ‘spring salmon’ or ‘chinook salmon’, but locally only called ‘king salmon’.

Lemma.Etymology: prob. orig. ‘float in water’, cf. Eyak %iʔuˀtłʼ%i ‘driftwood’, PA %i*ʔweˀtłʼ%i ‘pl. swim, float’

Example.Translation: She hung the towel that she washed outside.
Wash the sleep from your eyes.

Definition.Definition: S wash horizontal surface of O

Example.Translation: Let’s wash the (surface of the) table.
After we’ve washed the dishes we’ll play cards.
Example.Comment: Lit. ‘we will gamble’.

VerbTheme.Notes: Why is there no %ish-%i?
Verify stativity with perfective and habitual forms.

Definition.Definition: S tend to, have the habit of washing self

Grammar.Text: A rare stative version of the more usual active theme. Possibly an active/repetitive %i[+I]-...-kw%i derivation instead.

Example.Translation: He washes himself; he’s always washing himself.

VerbTheme.Notes: Check if %idaa-%i is incorporated: any possible preverbs (e.g. %iÿan=%i), reciprocal form, other phrases between it and rest of verb. If so, why %ish-%i contra Leer?

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘wash the outside, skin of self’

VerbTheme.Notes: Verify rep impfv form.

Definition.Definition: S wash away (out to sea) O from N

Grammar.Text: This is an unusual motion verb with %iN-dax̱ daak= (∅; -ch Rep)%i derived from the basic theme.

Example.Translation: It (swells) washed away them (possessions) from there (beach).

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘thing he washes the surface of it on’

Lemma.Comment: Also variably %iuwá%i with short final vowel.

Grammar.Text: Reduced form of %i-ÿ%i stative imperfective %ioowayáa%i ‘it₁ resembles it₂’. Syntactically like a postnominal adjective, but it could also be considered a compound noun head.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘eye-dollar’ or ‘eye-silver’, cf. silver dollar coins

Lemma.Etymology: < CJ %ibáštən%i < %ibástən%i < Eng. %iBoston%i; folk etymology derives this from Eng. %iWashington%i which is phonologically unlikely; %iKasheix̱sh%i Henry Denny and other elders knowing CJ affirm the connection
Lemma.Comment: Also %iWaashdan%i, %iWáashdan%i, %iWáashdaan%i, etc.

Definition.Definition: American, having to do with the United States of America

Encyclopedia.Text: This term derives from Chinook Jargon use of Eng. %iBoston%i describing sailors from Boston (Mass.) who were the vast majority early Americans on the Northwest Coast (e.g. John D’Wolf, Robert Gray, Robert Haswell, Joseph Ingraham, John Kendrick, William Dane Phelps, William Sturgis, etc.). Despite popular folk etymology, this does not derive from Eng. Washington which would instead be something like %iWáashintan%i. In CJ and other Northwest Coast languages this can refer to white people in general, but the meaning is exclusively ‘American’ in Tlingit, with %iDleit Ḵáa%i for the racial term. Often ‘Alaskan’ is excluded though of course part of the USA.

Definition.Definition: President of the United States of America

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘American blanket’, by contrast with %iGinjuchwaan xʼoowú%i ‘Hudson’s Bay blanket’ lit. ‘Canadian blanket’

Encyclopedia.Text: Woolen blankets manufactured by the Pendleton Woolen Mills company of Oregon. Not as well known as the Hudson’s Bay blanket (%iGinjuchwaan xʼóowu%i) but equally treasured, and used for the same purposes.

Definition.Comment: lit. ‘eye-dollar’ or ‘eye-silver’, cf. silver dollar coins

Grammar.Text: A loan from CJ which has undergone unusual syllabic metathesis in Northern Tlingit.

Definition.Definition: Vancouver, the city in British Columbia

Encyclopedia.Text: Not attested until recently, but this predictable borrowing may have been used in the past without record. Vancouver is the British Columbian counterpart to Seattle (%iSeeyaatl%i, q.v.) in Washington.

Definition.Definition: Vancouver, the city in Washington state across from Portland, Oregon

Encyclopedia.Text: Not attested, but since the name of the Washington city is identical to the city in British Columbia in English the Tlingit usage is straightforward.

Definition.Comment: this specific sense is more common than the generic sense below

Example.Example: Yées washéen a géekt satéen wé yaakw.
Example.Translation: A new motor sits at the stern of that boat.
She heard the sound of the engine.

Example.Example: A yée yawdudziteeyán du yaakw yík washéeni.
Example.Translation: They put his boat engine back in correctly.

Definition.Comment: the same generic sense as in English

Subentry.Comment: Various reduced forms exist for the second part, e.g. %ikatág̱ayí%i, %ikatág̱ayi%i, %ikatág̱ei%i, etc.

Definition.Definition: Engine cylinder connecting rod, typically ‘cylinder rod’ or just ‘rod’ in English
Bush, woody plant around or less than human height
The stem and leaves on which a flower or fruit grows

Grammar.Text: Not really inalienable, but treated as such for the distinct definition.

Lemma.Etymology: prob. < Tag. %imédzíh%i or similar Ath. lg., but %idz%i > %its%i unexplained

Encyclopedia.Text: The local subspecies are Porcupine caribou (%iR. t. granti%i Allen 1902) in the southwest Yukon and forest caribou (%iR. t. caribou%i Gmelin 1788) in southeast Yukon and BC. Essentially nonexistent on the coast, though some may occasionaly wander down river valleys. Caribou skins were and are highly valued, and much of the Athabaskan fur trade focused on caribou. Antlers were previously used for tools much like deer and moose, but are mostly restricted to artistic work today. Some Tlingits still prefer the femur or tibia for working skins.

Example.Example: Watsíx a lututúḵlʼi tléil tlax̱ ugé.
Example.Translation: The soft bone in a caribou nose is not very big.

Definition.Definition: Nares Mountain near Carcross, also sometimes ‘Fourth of July Mountain’

Encyclopedia.Text: The mountain called ‘Caribou Mountain’ in English is across the Tagish Road from this mountain, and is called %iYaadé Wduwanúk%i ‘Blowing Towards the Face’ in Tlingit and %iMétáátlʼè Shéchʼíí%i ‘Blowing on the Forehead’ in Tagish.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*xáːg(-iʰ)%i < PND %i*xʸeːg%i ‘empty shell, skeleton’; cf. PA %i*zeːgʸeˀ%i ‘corpse, invalid’; Eyak %isahxʷ%i prob. unrelated

Definition.Definition: Empty framework, as of an unfinished building
Evening, time of day around and after dusk

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %ixaˀsʼ%i < PND %i*xʸetsʼ%i ‘fish skin’ > Eyak %isitsʼ%i ‘fish skin’, Pre-PA %i*sitsʼ%i > PA %i*zəˀtsʼ%i ‘skin, hide’ > Chp. %iðə́ð%i ‘skin, hide’, Hup. %isitsʼ%i ‘skin, hide’

Grammar.Text: Usually occurs possessed.

Encyclopedia.Text: A major traditional use was as a glue, by placing fish skin between two items and applying pressure until the skin dried. Primarily taken from halibut for this purpose, though salmon and other fish were also used.

Lemma.Etymology: < PND %i*xʸo⁽⁾g%i ‘sandbar, dry ground’; cf. Pre-PA %i*saːg%i > PA %i*saːxʸ%i ‘sand’ > Chp. %iθay%i ‘sand’

Definition.Comment: esp. the prototypical plastic shopping bag

Lemma.Etymology: <? PND %i*šxaːn%i ‘old age/person, old’ > Eyak %ixaːnih%i ‘very old salmon’, Eyak %išyah%i ‘bad, nasty, disgusting’, PA %i*xʸaːn%i ‘old age’, PA %i*=yaːn%i ‘old’

Grammar.Text: The %in%i is optional because it is a nasalized vowel in French and thus may not be perceived as distinctive by Tlingit speakers. Often supplanted by English code-switched %iFrench%i, sometimes ‘Tlingitized’ as %iFench%i without /%pɹ%p/ but retaining /%pf%p/. For the fully borrowed English word see %iXwénch%i.

Encyclopedia.Text: See the %iXwénch%i entry for details.

Definition.Definition: One’s clan brother, (younger) male of the same clan or moiety
Prophets of God, warriors of God

Grammar.Text: Hapax legomenon, only known from Leer’s notes; may occur in Gospel of John however. The reason for rounding as %i–xwáaxʼu%i rather than %i*–xwáaxʼi%i is unknown since %i–xwáayi%i does not normally exhibit opaque rounding.

Encyclopedia.Text: Applied indiscriminately to all white French-speaking people, including especially Canadian French and European French but also Belgian French, Swiss French, etc. Contact between Canadian French and Tlingits was fairly limited but did occur both in Canadian territory and in American territory. There are a few people of Tlingit–French heritage but such marriages have always been fairly uncommon.

Example.Translation: A young man doesn’t get tired.
She was really tired after that.

Definition.Definition: S tire O, make O tired

VerbTheme.Notes: Needs more investigation.

Grammar.Text: Hapax legomenon, only known from Leer’s notes.

Definition.Definition: At, on, in, by, of, for

Grammar.Text: Indicates location at, on, in, or by the marked noun. Often attached to a relational noun possessed by the main noun, esp. %i–ká%i ‘horizontal surface’ or %i–tú%i ‘inside of hollow object’; the relational noun narrows the sense of the locative as e.g. %ia káxʼ%i ‘atop it’, %ia tóoxʼ%i ‘within it’, %ia x̱ánxʼ%i ‘beside it’, %ia x̱ooxʼ%i ‘among it’. Translates loosely as ‘of’ or ‘for’ when used with some verbs denoting mental states such as ‘hope’ or ‘despair’.

Example.Example: Ha yá yeedát yáaxʼ aan daak uwagút.
Example.Translation: So this moment he came out with it here.

Example.Example: Aadé yaa ajiklaháa áwé, yá Ltu.aa watyeexʼ, yaakw du een héent wudikʼítʼ, naháayi.
Example.Translation: While he was taking him there, at the mouth of Lituya Bay, the canoe swamped with them, the travelers.

Example.Example: Ha tlax̱ wáa lax̱éitlx̱ sá haa wootee, yá haa x̱ooxʼ yéi teeyí, yá haa tláa.
Example.Translation: So how very lucky we have been, this her being so among us, this mother of ours.

Example.Example: Yá éilʼ tlein káxʼ áyá ulhaashch.
Example.Translation: On this great ocean it would drift.

Example.Example: Chʼa yóo nax̱toosgeedí g̱óot áyá, i aat a daa s tuwli.aat hasdu tuwáxʼ áyú sigóo yéi yeeguwáatlʼ %ichance%i haa jeet yeeyteeyí.
Example.Translation: Without us needing to do anything, your paternal aunts thought that they wanted you to give us a chance for a short time.

Example.Example: Atx̱á daakahídixʼ gishoo taayí ḵa kʼwátʼ awdzig̱áax̱.
Example.Translation: She ordered bacon and eggs at the restaurant.

Grammar.Text: Always affected by rounding spread which may or may not be orthographically indicated. The plural suffix is not obligatory, so that many nouns referring to plural entities or locations occur without this plural suffix. Especially unnecessary when a verb indicates plurality, thus rendering plural marking on nouns redundant.

Example.Translation: Things that might warm your feelings.
The boat motored around the point.

Example.Example: Wé xʼaa g̱ei xóon tléil aan utí.
Example.Translation: The north wind doesn’t bother the shelter of the point.

Definition.Definition: Portage, passage across a point of land
Portage, passage across a point of land
Tip of branch of a plant, bush, or tree

Grammar.Text: May be dialectally restricted, Leer’s notes give it as ‘Stk’ i.e. from Wrangell.

Definition.Definition: O (group) die off completely, become completely extinct

Example.Example: L a daa haa tunatéeni, ldakát yax̱ ḵuyagux̱saxʼáaḵw.
Example.Translation: If we don’t take any action about it, they will all die off.

Example.Example: Tlél a káx̱ yiseixʼaag̱úḵ wé yaakw kakúxaa.
Example.Translation: Don’t forget about it, that boat bailer.

Example.Example: A kát tsé iseixʼáaḵw haa hít katíx̱ʼaayí!

Definition.Definition: S cause O to forget (about) N

Example.Example: Hasdu toowú néegu, a kát has sawtoolixʼáḵw.
Example.Translation: Their spiritual pain, we made them forget it.

Example.Example: Wudlixʼísʼi yé yáx̱ yatee wé koogántʼi.
Example.Translation: The way that it’s tangled where those windfalls are.

Definition.Definition: S cause O to be(come) tangled

Encyclopedia.Text: Blankets were worn as capes in the 19th century and into the 20th. This is still occasionally done today, but usually only while camping or aboard boats, and the blanket is no longer an item of daily clothing. Blankets are instead most often encountered as bedding. For the use of blankets as a form of wealth that is given away at potlatches, see the specialized term %ilʼée%i.

VerbTheme.Notes: Why does this theme occur as both %iaawax̱áa%i and %ioowax̱áa%i in the perfective?

Example.Translation: They ate as much as they wanted.

Example.Example: Atx̱a átch áwé uwax̱áa ax̱ kinaak.ádi.
Example.Comment: %iAtx̱a át%i is lit. ‘thing that eats it’.

Example.Translation: Long ago people used to eat squirrels.
I ate it into the roots of my hair.
Example.Comment: Said after rubbing grease into hair after a satisfying meal.

Definition.Definition: S eat O from (given by) N

Definition.Comment: variety of things, small amounts; Leer says ‘human or animal meat’

Example.Example: Ḵʼalkátsk yáxwchʼich yax̱ yawsix̱áa haa aaní kaadáx̱.
Example.Translation: Sea otters have devoured the yellowneck clams from our land.

Definition.Definition: S eat O (berries) directly from bush

Example.Example: Eelí chʼas l keeshx̱áaḵ, ḵukʼítʼ ḵu.aa.
Example.Translation: Don’t just eat the berries off the bush, pick them.

Grammar.Text: Edwards gives this as subject intransitive, but her example shows that it takes an object.

Example.Translation: He is rowing his rowboat quickly.
People used to always paddle to Copper River.

Definition.Definition: S transport O by boat to N

Example.Translation: They brought our food here by boat.

Definition.Definition: S transport O by boat around N

Example.Example: Káa tlein yíkt át yawduwax̱aa wé aanḵáawu.
Example.Translation: The rich man is being driven around in a limousine.

Grammar.Text: Incorporated inalienable noun used in verbs, derived from the inalienable noun %i–x̱aawú%i ‘fur, hair, quills’.

Example.Comment: lit. ‘pointy-furred’
lit. ‘white-furred’

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*χaʰgʷ%i < %i*–χaʰˈguː%i < PND %i*χa(h)gʸ%i > Eyak %i–yə-ł-χahdz-ł%i ‘hand-%scl%s-scratch-%sinstr%s’ i.e. ‘fingernail’, Aht. %ide-l-ɣaːdz%i ‘make a scratching, grinding, crunching noise’, Nav. %itsʼi-ɣaz%i ‘scraping, scratching sound’

Definition.Definition: Salmon, any species of %iOnorhynchus%i that is anadromous, migrating from ocean to fresh water for spawning
Fish, can refer to any kind of fish other than sharks

Grammar.Text: The perfective is rare for this theme and all derived from it; usually the imperfective is used instead.
Leer says this specifically means ‘become’, though examples are lacking. Note %ig̱a%i-conjugation.

Example.Translation: That china doll has a hairy head.

Lemma.Comment: Implies an alienable noun %ix̱aaw%i which does not occur outside of compounds, thus this inalienable noun is fossilized from the alienable noun.

Example.Example: Wé x̱ʼalakʼáchʼ x̱aawú ax̱ keidlí x̱ʼéit yawdlig̱ích.
Example.Translation: The porcupine’s quills stuck in my dog’s mouth.

Definition.Comment: the ‘yellow-cedar’ name is usual in Tlingit country

Encyclopedia.Text: Botanists investigating this tree’s genetic history have assigned it to several different genera: %iChamaecyparis n.%i (D. Don) Spach 1841, %iCallitropsis n.%i Ørsted 1864, %iXanthocyparis n.%i (D. Don) Farjon et Harder 2002)

Example.Example: Dax̱áchxʼi yaakw tlénxʼ át has anax̱áchch.
Example.Translation: Tugboats go around towing large ships.

Grammar.Text: Nominalization of %ix̱alikʼáchʼ%i ‘it is pointy-furred’.

Lemma.Comment: Means both ‘bless’ and ‘luck’. Note that the verb root varies between %i√x̱etl%i, %i√x̱eʼtl%i, and %i√x̱éitl˟%i across themes.

VerbTheme.Notes: E 09 has this with invariable %i√x̱éitl˟%i and the %i-ch%i repetitive stem as %i–x̱éitlch%i. But N&S 73 give the progressive %i-n%i stem as %i–x̱étl%i and the perfective with %i-h%i as %i–x̱éitl%i implying %i√x̱eʼtl%i, so the root idiolectally (dialectally?) varies. The most common stems will be /CV́ːC/ %i–x̱éitl%i so the invariable root may be an innovative generalization.

Example.Comment: Lit. ‘hopefully you (have) become blessed’

VerbTheme.Notes: Check negative form. %i–x̱eitl%i or %i–x̱éitl%i? Latter implies %i√x̱eʼtl%i.

Example.Translation: It is a thing that I was blessed with.

Example.Comment: N&S 73 do not include the expected ergative %i-ch%i.

VerbTheme.Notes: Check negative form. %i–x̱eitl%i or %i–x̱éitl%i? Latter implies %i√x̱eʼtl%i.

Definition.Definition: S verbally bless O via words, prayer

Example.Translation: A baby’s mouth is always slimy.
That skin got scorched (shriveled up due to heat).
The back of his hand was burned.
The edge of his hand was burned.

Example.Example: Ax̱ jín x̱walix̱ʼéx̱ʼ, yú sdoox tóot ax̱a.aagí.
Example.Translation: I burnt my hand building a fire in the stove.
He scalded his hand with hot water.

Example.Example: Du tlʼeḵshá awlix̱ʼéx̱ʼ wé sdoox káxʼ.
Example.Translation: He burned his fingertip on that stove.

Definition.Definition: S scorch, burn, scald the surface of O
Definition.Notes: Might also be classificatory %ika-%i referring to small round objects.

Example.Translation: The sun is warping this lumber.

Example.Example: Áyá a káxʼ áyá kéi x̱ʼuswushix̱ʼílʼ.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*χʼʷeinaː-yeiɬʼ%i < %i*χʼʷaynaː-yayɬʼ%i, the older Tah. loan clarifies the original morphology; orig. meant ‘roasting-stick elderberry’, but the reason is unclear.

Encyclopedia.Text: Originally applied to the indigenous Nootka Rose, now broadened to include any similar rose species.

Definition.Definition: Rose bush as opposed to other parts of a rose
The stem and leaves of a rose flower
Rosehip, fruit of a rose bush

Grammar.Text: Usually superseded by %ikʼinchéiyi%i, but this descriptive compound is sometimes used as an alternative.

Definition.Definition: Roasting stick, grilling stick, barbecue stick

Grammar.Text: Formed from a verb root %i√x̱ʼu%i with %i-n%i stem variation and the %i-aa%i instrument suffix. The root is otherwise unattested and its meaning is unknown.

Encyclopedia.Text: A roasting stick is made from a green, finger- or thumb-width stick which is split at one end. Meat is placed in the split and then the split is bound back together. The meat may be additionally supported by cross skewers called variously %itlʼéekʼát%i, %itutséegi%i, %ikatsóox̱u%i, or %ix̱ʼwéinaa tusheeyí%i, q.v.

Definition.Definition: Proxmal determiner, closest to speaker, roughly equivalent with Eng. ‘the’ + ‘this’

Grammar.Text: This and the other determiners were called ‘demonstratives’ by Naish & Story, but they cannot appear without a noun and hence are not true demonstratives; cf. %iyáatʼaa%i etc.

Example.Translation: The Northern Lights are really moving around this evening.

Example.Example: Kaldag̱éináx̱ yaa gax̱tooḵóox̱, tlél g̱wadlaan yá éix̱ʼ yík.
Example.Translation: We will travel along slowly, it’s not deep in this slough.

Grammar.Text: The thematic irrealis %iu-%i prefix is present in realis forms.

Example.Translation: That one that looks like it.
Example.Comment: Relativized form.
Note inner distributive %idag̱a-%i, so ‘each one doesn’t resemble anything’.

Example.Translation: My younger sister looks like my mother.
It was formless; it didn’t resemble anything.

Definition.Definition: S and O resemble each other

Grammar.Text: The reciprocal form with %iwoosh=...[+D]-%i added to the preceding theme, which though entirely predictable is common enough to note here for clarity.

Example.Translation: They always look like each other.
Their barks (of trees) just resemble each other.
They are starting to resemble each other.
Buy them if they resemble each other.

VerbTheme.Notes: Verify stativity.

Definition.Definition: O be like N as kin due to a clan relationship

Example.Translation: I am like his older brother.
You are going to be as a brother to me.

VerbTheme.Notes: Poorly documented. Check if really active. Not clear which argument is N or O.

Example.Translation: He is likening it to it.

Example.Notes: Originally Louis Shotridge, so from Boas 1917?
Originally Louis Shotridge, so from Boas 1917?

VerbTheme.Notes: Poorly documented. Check if actually active.

Definition.Definition: S make O like N as kin due to a clan relationship

Example.Translation: They were made to be like brothers.

Encyclopedia.Text: The primary referent is the blue mussel (%iM. trossulus%i) common to the Alaskan coast south to California, as well as across the North Pacific south to Hokkaidō. Also included are the common blue mussel (%iM. edulis%i) and more generally any species in the %iMytilus%i genus, excepting the California mussel (%iM. californianus%i) which is specifically referred to as %iyéesʼ%i (q.v.). Mussels are generally looked down upon as a poor person’s food, presumably because they are so easy to obtain. Nonetheless, Tlingit people harvest and eat them and some families have well developed recipes for preparation and storage of mussels. Children sometimes eat them while playing on the beach, usually by threading the meat onto a stick and toasting it over a fire; toasting mussels on the beach can be a child’s first lone efforts at cooking. De Laguna (1972: 392) says her consultants claimed that mussels in Yakutat were never poisonous, but could be elsewhere in Southeast Alaska.

Example.Example: Wé yéi kuwoox̱ʼu yaakw yá yéil a káa gax̱toonéegwálʼ.
Example.Translation: We will paint this raven here on the widest side of the skiff.
The boat will get stuck on the beach.

Lemma.Etymology: < Eyak %i diyaˀqudaˀt%i, influenced by Tl. %iyaakw%i ‘canoe’; various folk etymologies exist

Grammar.Text: Usually encountered possessed and hence treated as inalienable, but actually an alienable noun.

Lemma.Etymology: perh. derived from %iÿat%i ‘child’ > %iÿats%i ‘kiddy’ by imitation of child speech plus diminutive %i-kʼw%i, but reason for final rounding and vocalization is unclear
Lemma.Comment: Special plural form %i–yátsxʼi%i lacks the %i-kʼu%i, according with the latter being diminutive.

Example.Example: Dagwatgiyáa lú yayátʼ ḵa yéi kwlisáa.
Example.Translation: A hummingbird’s beak is long and skinny.

Example.Comment: Lit. “he is long-boned”.

Example.Translation: How long will he be there?
It will be a long time.
The tide is going way out.
Example.Comment: Lit. “the mudflats are getting long”.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*ÿiʰ%i < %i*ʔÿiʰ%i; cf. PA %i*-eː%i which converts nouns of time to adverbs of time

Grammar.Text: An unproductive root that occurs in a number of time expressions and as an incorporated noun. Does not occur free except in a few fixed expressions.

Definition.Definition: You all, you guys, second person plural pronoun

Grammar.Text: Older spelling of %iyi%i, pronunciation is identical. Still preferred by some writers.

Lemma.Etymology: perh. < %i*ÿiʰ-daʰ-t%i ‘time-around-%spnct%s’, but there may be a distinct %i*–dat%i root

Encyclopedia.Text: Some speakers make use of this phrase as a narrative device, as for example %iHéenákʼw Tʼáaxʼ%i Forrest DeWitt’s habit of starting most narratives with %i«Yá yeedát ḵu.aa»%i.

Definition.Definition: During, within a given period of time

Grammar.Text: Apparently formed from the %iyee%i ‘time’ root plus the possessive suffix %i-ÿí%i thus lit. ‘of a time’.

Lemma.Etymology: < PT %i*yayɬ%i, perh. earlier %i*yaˀyɬ%i < %i*yayʔaɬ%i or %i*yaˀyaɬ%i, cf. Haida %iyaʔaɬ%i ‘Raven’ (myth figure) borrowed from an unattested earlier Tlingit form.

Definition.Comment: or ‘crow’ for many Inland Tlingit elders, who do not distinguish the two in Eng.

Encyclopedia.Text: The all-black Common raven appears very similar to the Northwestern crow (%iC. caurinus%i Baird 1858) and the American crow (%iC. brachyrhynchos%i Brehm 1822). The raven and Northwestern crow are coextensive in Southeast Alaska, but some towns may have larger concentrations of one or the other species, and there seems to be a general decline of crow population along the northerly axis of the country. American crows are only found in the interior and are fairly rare, so that ravens are by far the dominant black bird in Inland Tlingit territory. Ravens are larger than crows and of huskier build, with pronounced hackles on the throat that can appear like a shaggy beard, with a larger and sturdier beak, and with head feathers that are often raised in a scruffy mane. In flight ravens will soar far more often than crows, and at close to medium distances the wedge-shaped tail of a raven can be easily distinguished from the straight fan-shaped tail of a crow. Raven wings are also larger and longer and the primary feathers are bigger with greater gaps between them at the end of the wings. Both ravens and crows may engage in remarkable aerobatic manoeuvres, but ravens do so more often and more elaborately. Ravens typically prefer to walk between nearby locations on the ground whereas crows more frequently are willing to fly short distances. In towns ravens are less skittish, and will typically sidle away from a human rather than fleeing. Ravens often use a running or hopping start off the ground for takeoff due to their greater mass, whereas crows almost always take off from the ground in a single leap. The basic raven call is deeper and more sonorous than the raspy call of a crow. Ravens also have a much larger and more varied repertoire of calls, including bell-ringing notes and complex sequences of clicks, chitters, and croaks. In Tlingit the raven’s basic call is %ig̱áa%i either alone or in a pair with some optional uvular trilling and a low back vowel, whereas a crow call is a higher pitched %ix̱áa%i with a low front vowel that may be repeated in pairs. Like most animals, ravens may be talked to directly using appropriate kin terms for the speaker, so that a Raven moiety man might address a raven as %iax̱ kéilkʼ%i ‘my sister’s child’ and a Wolf/Eagle moiety woman might address a raven as %iax̱ káalkʼw%i ‘my brother’s child’. Ravens are not generally treated as much older than middle-aged, in contrast with eagles who are often spoken to as though they were elderly and socially senior. Ravens make for troublesome and difficult pets, but some people do regularly feed wild ravens. Since ravens are able to distinguish individual human faces, it is not uncommon to hear of ravens that follow particularly generous individuals around a town. The early morning arrival of ravens at a settlement serves as the traditional marker for morning, and the departure of ravens to their roosts away from town also marks the beginning of the evening. Killing of ravens is rare but not unknown; usually ravens are shot because they have become a nuisance by breaking into smokehouses or dwellings, by tearing apart garbage and attracting bears, and so forth; in older days a raven might be shot if it was felt to be bringing bad luck on an individual. Ravens are never eaten, but feathers may be collected from dead individuals. Raven behaviour is a favourite topic of discussion, and Tlingit people often have hours worth of stories about the many fascinating or funny things they have witnessed or heard of ravens doing. Ravens traditionally were not equated with the Raven of mythology but were felt to be related (De Laguna 1972: 829). In the past people would listen carefully to ravens and study them, even asking them questions about current events and the future (id.).

Definition.Comment: member of a Raven moiety clan

Grammar.Text: Linguistically differentiated from ordinary ravens only by capitalization, not in speech.

Encyclopedia.Text: The Tlingit name of Raven derives from the verb roots %i√yel%i and %i√yéil˟%i which mean ‘deceive, lie, cheat’, thus %iYéil%i is literally something like ‘Deceiver’ or ‘Liar’. The latter root, being invariable, is probably derived from Raven’s name, but the former may or may not be derived. One can translate Tlingit’s concepts of cheating or deceiving in English as ‘Ravening’. Raven is both a creator and a trickster. He is male, having impregnated a few females in various situations, and there are stories involving him pretending to be female with varying success. His grandfather %iNaas Shakée Yéil%i (‘Raven at the Head of the Nass’) was in many traditions the true the creator of the world, but he hoarded all sources of light in keeping with the typical corvid love for shiny or bright objects. Raven used trickery to become %iNaas Shakée Yéil%i’s grandson and then cheated him out of the lights which became the Sun, Moon, and Stars. Raven went on to steal fresh water from Petrel (%iG̱anook%i), to trick Owl (%iDzískʼw%i) into bringing fire from a volcano, and through other often devious means brought Tlingits the tools and technologies they needed to survive and prosper. But beyond these deeds with essentially honorable results, he also took every opportunity to satiate his incredible gluttony, and delighted in cheating and fooling almost every entity or individual he encountered. Raven has been fooled and embarassed as well, being publicly intoxicated and cheated out of various things over time. Extensive cycles of Raven stories were collected by Swanton (1909: 3–21, 80–154) and De Laguna (1972: 839–872). Through not entirely clear circumstances he became the primary crest of the Raven moiety; some clan histories provide explanations but others simply take Raven’s symbolic importance as an unexplained fact. Raven’s activities have resulted in many landmarks across the breadth and length of %iLingít Aaní%i, and places outside of traditional Tlingit territory have also shown signs of Raven’s presence. Stories about Raven that involve modern day entities and situations continue to spread, and Raven is still the essential figure in Tlingit myth and philosophy. He serves as a delightfully obscene example of what %inot%i to do, the sort of person that Tlingits should aspire %inot%i to become, yet still provides invaluable insight about the universe and about human societies. In De Laguna’s (1972: 843) words: “it is not the superior creative or well-meaning acts of Raven … that can explain the popularity of Raven stories. Raven is enjoyed because he embodies all the worst faults and failings of humanity, and he is funny because he does all the things that people would really like to do, but dare not attempt, and sometimes dare not even think.”

Example.Example: Yá uháan haa naax̱ sitee, Yéil áyá haa shukáx̱ sitee.
Example.Translation: We who are of our clan, Raven is our main crest.

Example.Example: X̱áat yís áwé has akawliník Yéilch, wé Kéidladi ḵa Kag̱eet.
Example.Translation: Raven talked the Seagull and Loon out of the salmon.

Grammar.Text: Occurs as the possessor of a noun or as a non-head element in a compound.

Example.Translation: It is black and blue, obsidian coloured.

Definition.Definition: S pretend to do, to be O

Example.Translation: He’s always pretending about himself with people.

Example.Example: Chʼa wéidáx̱ atsʼéilʼi ash naayís awliyél.
Example.Translation: He just pretended that rags from over there were for her clothing.
He got mad because he had been fooled.

Example.Example: Ḵusax̱án tin ḵut kei ash layélch.
Example.Translation: He keeps deceiving her with love.

Definition.Definition: O (human) have discoloured skin, e.g. bruising or jaundice
S dye, stain, change the colour of O

Example.Translation: I’m going to polish my shoes.
Example.Comment: Not polish as in ‘buff’ or ‘shine’ but as in ‘apply shoe polish’.

Encyclopedia.Text: Unidentified substance used for a very black colour in painting. Said to be a mineral obtained in trade from the Coast Tsimshian.

Definition.Definition: You all, you guys, second person plural pronoun

Lemma.Comment: Nominalization of verb %iyoo aan kaawa.áa%i ‘it earthquaked’ (see %i√.a%i), but not derived from the imperfective form.

Definition.Definition: Distal determiner, farthest from speaker, roughly equivalent with Eng. ‘the’ + ‘that’

Grammar.Text: This and the other determiners were called ‘demonstratives’ by Naish & Story, but they cannot appear without a noun and hence are not true demonstratives; cf. %iyóotʼaa%i etc.

Example.Translation: Those grey currants have already been boiled.

Definition.Definition: At, on, in, by, of, for

Grammar.Text: Allomorph of %i-xʼ%i used after words ending in /%pCV%p/ syllables (short vowels only, so not e.g. /%pCVː%p/). Realized as glottalized /%pCVˀ%p/ in Tongass Tlingit, falling /%pCV́V̀%p/ in Southern Tlingit, and long high /%pCV́ː%p/ elsewhere. Represented as %i-ʼ%i due to its realization in Tongass Tlingit.

Example.Translation: It would be pounded there by the waves.

Example.Example: Kawóot teen ḵʼeikaxwéin a káa kaḵá.
Example.Translation: Embroider a flower on it with beads.
